story:
Our Story

Based in Ypsilanti, Toronto, Brooklyn, Champaign-Urbana and  Dallas-Fort Worth, The Cultural Gutter was founded in 2003 by writer, filmmaker and game designer Jim Munroe and comics critic and artist Guy Leshinski to provide clear-eyed, thoughtful writing on disreputable art. Since then, we've had twelve editors in two countries and eight cities write on comics, genre films, Indian b-movies, tv, science fiction, fantasy, horror, romance and video games. In all that time we paid our writers, both our editors and guest stars. Then we lost our funding grant, but a small, rag-tag band of donors joined forces with the Gutter to keep us online and help us keep our commitment to paying writers for their work. Thus, the Gutterthon was born. And thanks to our readers like you, the Cultural Gutter has been sustained without ads, subscriptions or a paywall.

At the Gutter we like to think we offer something special and we're kind of proud of it. The Gutter features thoughtful, well-written articles on topics like: American Sci Fi Folk horror; Godzilla and realism; relatability and Planet Of The Apes; letting something you love reboot; romance and the belief that people can change; Janelle Monáe as the American cool; Ancient Egypt in contemporary Indian film; Hellraiser and "development hell"; mastering the art of losing; "Tilda Swinton: Secret Scottish Samurai"; Duran Duran & William S. Burroughs' Wild Boys; and so much Adventure Time. So please click "Back It" and keep the Gutter flowing with the writing you love. Even if you can only throw in a buck, we will thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $1600 and it breaks down to $250/year/writer or about $20/article; $250/year for the Evil Overlord for publishing, promoting, and updating the site on our new platform, finding new writers, day-to-day site management, making sure the perks are shipped out, and continuing work on The Cultural Gutter Must Be Destroyed, a collection of essays from the Gutter's current line-up. Approximately $200 will go towards website hosting and domain registration. The remaining funds will go toward perks, shipping, promotional materials, Indiegogo and Paypal fees, and paying guest writers.

In return, you get our undying and eternal thanks and your choice of some sweet perks. And, hopefully, writing that entertains and interests you.

Perks Include:

This year let your consciousness expand with the next logical step in psychic evolution: The Gutterthon Cosmic totes and mugs featuring this year's mind-expanding banner designed by Brian Kirby of Shelf Life Clothing Company! This year's Gutterthon Cosmic poster is a staggering 24 x 36 inches!

A Cultural Gutter Membership package including a numbered and dated CG Membership Card and a decryption key for decoding the CG Secret Messages posted at the top of the Sponsors Page, which we plan to get back on in 2020 now that we've moved to the new site/platform.

My Pretty Zombie has created two swank nail polish and eyeshadow sets paying tribute to Squalo, everyone's favorite star of the Italian shark attack movie, L'Ultimo Squalo, aka, The Last Shark, aka, Great White! Enjoy the sparkly microglitter blue-blackness of "Squalo in Space" as Squalo makes you and the cosmos more fabulous. "Scream, Squalo! Scream!" is a gray based pigment with a blue shift making both a stunning eyeshadow and matte nail polish.

A signed, print copy of The Cultural Gutter Presents Secret Diagrams of Mantis Fist! Long rumored and often denied, the Cultural Gutter's have been presented in this volume for the first time. In publishing these diagrams, we hope to reassure those who have claimed that we have been hiding martial arts secrets for our own benefit. Instead, this volume contains not only the recently discovered diagrams detailing stances of Mantis Fist kung fu, but places them in context with a brief historical overviews, film reviews and even the accusations of diagram skeptics in their own words. Featuring art by author/illustrator Evan Munday and crazy talk by the Gutter's own Carol Borden. Designed by friend of the Gutter, Andrew Nahem.

Author and cult film writing icon Todd Stadtman has provided signed print set of his SF Punk Trio books: Please Don't Be Waiting for Me; So Good It's Bad; and, Never Divided. Set in 1970s and early 1980s San Francisco punk scene, the series chronicles the adventures of  "Scott, Bridge, Benny, and Micah, a tightknit band of teenage punk rockers with a habit of finding themselves on the wrong side of the law."

A Miss Namikawa mug featuring a space lady and her love beyond all computation designed by Brian Kirby of Shelf Life Clothing Co.! And a Miss Namikawa notecard set featuring the same design!

The Best of British Fantasy 2018 edited by friend of the Gutter, Jared Shurin.  "The anthology contains over twenty brilliant stories of the strange and fantastic, complete with mermaids, impossible quizzes, sorcerous rogues, magic swords, towering monsters, ghostly lovers, unreachable islands, numerous apocalypses, a particularly irritating local councillor, and bees."

The Outcast Hours, edited by Mahvesh Murad and Jared Shurin. "These are the stories of people who live at night: under neon and starlight, and never the light of the sun. These are the stories of poets and police, tourists and traders; the hidden and the forbidden; the lonely and the lovers. This is their time." The Outcast Hours gathers over two dozen brand-new stories from award-winning writers across genres and continents, including bold new fiction from Marina Warner, Frances Hardinge, China Miéville, Sami Shah, Omar Robert Hamilton, Kuzhali Manickavel, Will Hill, Indrapramit Das, Silvia Moreno-Garcia, Jeffrey Alan Love, Maha Khan Phillips, and many, many more."

Our friends at Fox Spirit Books have donated digital copies of four titles to the Gutterthon Cosmic. All three of the noir anthologies edited by friend of the Gutter Kate Laity are available for your reading pleasure. And all three noir anthologies include a story by the Gutter's own Carol Borden.

Weird Noir is a genre-bending collection mixing madness and the hardboiled. "On the gritty backstreets of a crumbling city, tough dames and dangerous men trade barbs, witticisms and a few gunshots. But there’s a new twist where urban decay meets the eldritch borders of another world: WEIRD NOIR. Featuring thugs who sprout claws and fangs, gangsters with tentacles and the occasional succubus siren. The ambience is pure noir but the characters aren’t just your average molls and mugs—the vamps might just be vamps. It’s Patricia Highsmith meets Shirley Jackson or Dashiell Hammett filtered through H. P. Lovecraft. Mad, bad and truly dangerous to know, but irresistible all the same."

In Noir Carnival "the carnies bring you stories, a heady mix of shadows and candy floss, dreams gone sour and nights that go on too long. Let them lure you into the tent. Carnival: whether you picture it as a traveling fair in the back roads of America or the hedonistic nights of the pre-Lenten festival where masks hide faces while the skin glories in its revelation, it’s about spectacle, artificiality and the things we hide behind the greasepaint or the tent flap. Let these writers lead you on a journey into that heart of blackened darkness and show you what’s behind the glitz. Underneath, we’re all freaks after all…"

Drag Noir is a genre- and gender-bending collection of stories. "This is where glamour meets grit, where everyone’s wearing a disguise (whether they know it or not) and knowing the players takes a lot more than simply reading the score cards. Maybe everyone’s got something to hide, but they’ve got something to reveal, too. Scratch the surface and explore what secrets lie beneath — it’s bound to cost someone…a lot."

Graham Wynd's Love Is A Grift starts out with obsession and just might end in death. "How does obsession begin? For one hit man it starts with a target he just can’t kill. She leads him on a deadly spree across Europe. With every step he’s in deeper. Each crime binds them together like a vow and only death can part them. But will it be his… or hers?

Love is a Grift and the other stories in this collection offer a fresh take on a classic genre, that begins with obsession and most often ends with death."

A Dull Gift Package including one copy of Basil Morley, Esq.'s delightful tome, How to be Dull: Standing Out Next to Genius: two postcards; two stickers; two badges; and a handful of vintage (i.e. faded) Classic Martini napkins. "Are you, too, a refuge from the relentless pressure to be 'creative?' Have you had enough of 'pushing the envelope' and 'thinking outside the box' to last the next three lifetimes or more? Stop trying to succeed and learn to be DULL. Dull people may not end up presidents of the free world or at top of the pop charts, but they do get on with a minimum of fuss and practically no pressure. Your weekends will remain free. You will not need to purchase a lot of expensive equipment. There are no rigid rules to follow. You can idle through this book or simply give up when your curiosity has been exhausted. This volume makes a great gift for your boss or any other dynamic go-getters you know. Wink and tell them it’s all in good fun, but get ready for a blissful calm to descend once they have grasped the simple art of dullness. The late Basil Morley, esq., spent a lifetime judiciously avoiding the limelight in one dull pursuit after another. He may be unable to do so in the afterlife, as there remain treasures like this pamphlet to be looted from his jumble of notebooks, cabinets and miniature terrariums. Though he might quail at the sudden wave of untoward attention, there is little he can do about it now. 'I laughed, I cried, I quoted the best lines to Boccaccio.' — Geoffrey Chaucer 'He stole the best bits from me, the bastard.' — Dorothy Parker 'I have to revise my famous essay on laughter now.' — Henri Bergson."

A Medusa Moleskine handprinted by the Gutter's own Carol! A light brown 3.5 x 5.5" pocket Moleskine with a light green Medusa handprinted on the cover. Guaranteed 100% non-petrifying!

A 5-pack of "Monsterland, Ogasawara Island" postcards designed by friend of the Gutter Brian Kirby of Shelf Life Clothing Company! Let loved ones know you wish they were there as you tour "The Bonin Islands, also known as the Ogasawara Islands...an archipelago of over 30 subtropical and tropical islands some 520 mi directly south of Tokyo, Japan. Since 1999, all of the Earth's monsters have been collected and confined there in an area known as Monsterland."

SOLD OUT: A swank Cinema Detroit t-shirts from our friends at Cinema Detroit. Show your support for the only truly independent movie theater in the metro Detroit area and look good doing it!

SOLD OUT: A Medusa Moleskine handprinted by the Gutter's own Carol!  A dark green 3.5 x 5.5" pocket Moleskine with a light green Medusa handprinted on the cover. Guaranteed 100% non-petrifying! Declared "quality items. KWALITAY" by author Chlöe Yates!

SOLD OUT: Have a noggin filled with spooky thoughts? Proud of your endoskeletal cranium? Show off either or both this with this beanie / watch cap with a subtle skull pattern in multicolored wool made and donated by Huge Shark! They are knit of black alpaca with multicolored wool. They'll fit from a medium woman's head to a medium man's head. Hand wash/dry flat.

SOLD OUT: Keep your mitts warm with these fingerless owl mittens knit by Huge Shark. They have a secret knit owl pattern on them! Brown tweed (85% wool, 10% silk, 5% cashmere). Sized to fit a large woman to medium-large man's hand. Hand wash/dry flat.

SOLD OUT: A print copy of Meredith Lewis' new book, Ask For The Moon: Innovation at Shaw Brothers Studios! "In the 1960s Shaw Brothers Studios revolutionised martial arts filmmaking. Movie mogul Sir Run Run Shaw developed a way to churn out lavish blockbusters quickly and cheaply. An assembly line approach kept his filmmakers busy but access to an extraordinary pool of resources meant they could 'ask for the moon.' This book is a case study exploring how a brilliant, driven entrepreneur and his audaciously creative filmmakers conducted a bold experiment in business and movie-making innovation."

SOLD OUT: A print copy of Cocktails & Capers: Cult Films, Crime, Cocktails, and Cool by the Gutter's own Keith Allison! "Explore a world populated by masked marvels and murderous maniacs, venomous vamps and gentleman thieves, swingin' spies and cantankerous crooners. Cocktails & Capers collects essays covering cinematic, pop culture, true crime, and cocktail history, including: Sweet Smell of Success and the nightclubs of Swing Street; A.J. Raffles, gentleman thief; Louis Feuillade's Fantomas and Les Vampires; the history of the Martini; Diabolik, Kriminal, and the skeleton suit-clad maniacs of Italy and Turkey; James Bond, amari, negronis, and how Ian Fleming and Lucky Luciano saved the Allied invasion of Sicily; the history of masked Mexican wrestlers and the partnership of El Santo and Blue Demon; and the weird, wild world of the Rat Pack in the 1960s and how the grim, violent Matt Helm novels became slapstick spy spoofs starring Dean Martin. These are tales of mobsters, movie stars, masked men, torch singers, crooners, and hustlers -- with dozens of cocktail recipes and music suggestions that pair perfectly."

SOLD OUT: A digital copy of Dracula In Istanbul, aka, Turkish Dracula, edited by Neon Harbor's Ed Glaser. "For the first time in English comes a remarkable literary discovery. In 1928, Turkish author Ali Rıza Seyfioğlu pirated Bram Stoker’s Dracula, rewriting it with new material, patriotic overtones, and Islam. A rare example of a 'bootleg' novel, it’s also the first adaptation to plainly identify Dracula as the historical warlord Vlad the Impaler."

SOLD OUT: a needle-felted critter from Venus made by friend of the Gutter, Kerry Fristoe. This critter's name is Beulah and she is beautiful! You might recognize the critter from It Conquered The World!

SOLD OUT: A gorgeous horror-themed motivational poster made by Steve Jencks!

If we don't reach our goal, we'll use the funds to print and ship your perks and see how much we can pay each editor. If we exceed our goal, we would use the extra funds to print promotional materials or hire more guest writers. If we significantly exceed our goal, we will use our funds to give the writers a raise this year.

We will be unlocking more perks as the campaign continues, but even $1 gets our Undying Thanks! (Really, a buck does make a difference).

The Impact

We like to think that the Gutter offers something special: Clear-eyed, thoughtful and thought-provoking writing on disreputable art. If you donate or support the campaign by sharing, you will help keep the Gutter online and running; support our particular take on disreputable art; and help support paying writers for their work.

We ran a successful last fundraiser year, and, thanks to everyone's help, we escaped our old webhost, moved to a new webhost, and have been working on making the new Gutter as good as can be. And we kept the Gutter going. The Cultural Gutter's survival depends on Gutterthon and on you. We know it's a difficult time for creators of all kinds, that platforms are valued more than content. But we believe with your help, we can keep the Gutter flowing with quality writing. 

We know that times are hard for a lot of people and any little bit helps, even a retweet or sharing our campaign on Facebook. Indiegogo has tools that make it easy. Please consider using them even if you can't contribute money. Anything you do to help is appreciated.

Thank you from all of us at The Cultural Gutter!

In Noir Carnival "the carnies bring you stories, a heady mix of shadows and candy floss, dreams gone sour and nights that go on too long. Let them lure you into the tent. Carnival: whether you picture it as a traveling fair in the back roads of America or the hedonistic nights of the pre-Lenten festival where masks hide faces while the skin glories in its revelation, it’s about spectacle, artificiality and the things we hide behind the greasepaint or the tent flap. Let these writers lead you on a journey into that heart of blackened darkness and show you what’s behind the glitz. Underneath, we’re all freaks after all…"
Drag Noir is a genre- and gender-bending collection of stories. "This is where glamour meets grit, where everyone’s wearing a disguise (whether they know it or not) and knowing the players takes a lot more than simply reading the score cards. Maybe everyone’s got something to hide, but they’ve got something to reveal, too. Scratch the surface and explore what secrets lie beneath — it’s bound to cost someone…a lot."
Graham Wynd's Love Is A Grift starts out with obsession and just might end in death. "How does obsession begin? For one hit man it starts with a target he just can’t kill. She leads him on a deadly spree across Europe. With every step he’s in deeper. Each crime binds them together like a vow and only death can part them. But will it be his… or hers?
Love is a Grift and the other stories in this collection offer a fresh take on a classic genre, that begins with obsession and most often ends with death."
A Dull Gift Package including one copy of Basil Morley, Esq.'s delightful tome, How to be Dull: Standing Out Next to Genius: two postcards; two stickers; two badges; and a handful of vintage (i.e. faded) Classic Martini napkins. "Are you, too, a refuge from the relentless pressure to be 'creative?' Have you had enough of 'pushing the envelope' and 'thinking outside the box' to last the next three lifetimes or more? Stop trying to succeed and learn to be DULL. Dull people may not end up presidents of the free world or at top of the pop charts, but they do get on with a minimum of fuss and practically no pressure. Your weekends will remain free. You will not need to purchase a lot of expensive equipment. There are no rigid rules to follow. You can idle through this book or simply give up when your curiosity has been exhausted. This volume makes a great gift for your boss or any other dynamic go-getters you know. Wink and tell them it’s all in good fun, but get ready for a blissful calm to descend once they have grasped the simple art of dullness. The late Basil Morley, esq., spent a lifetime judiciously avoiding the limelight in one dull pursuit after another. He may be unable to do so in the afterlife, as there remain treasures like this pamphlet to be looted from his jumble of notebooks, cabinets and miniature terrariums. Though he might quail at the sudden wave of untoward attention, there is little he can do about it now. 'I laughed, I cried, I quoted the best lines to Boccaccio.' — Geoffrey Chaucer 'He stole the best bits from me, the bastard.' — Dorothy Parker 'I have to revise my famous essay on laughter now.' — Henri Bergson."
A Medusa Moleskine handprinted by the Gutter's own Carol! A light brown 3.5 x 5.5" pocket Moleskine with a light green Medusa handprinted on the cover. Guaranteed 100% non-petrifying!
A 5-pack of "Monsterland, Ogasawara Island" postcards designed by friend of the Gutter Brian Kirby of Shelf Life Clothing Company! Let loved ones know you wish they were there as you tour "The Bonin Islands, also known as the Ogasawara Islands...an archipelago of over 30 subtropical and tropical islands some 520 mi directly south of Tokyo, Japan. Since 1999, all of the Earth's monsters have been collected and confined there in an area known as Monsterland."
SOLD OUT: A swank Cinema Detroit t-shirts from our friends at Cinema Detroit. Show your support for the only truly independent movie theater in the metro Detroit area and look good doing it!
SOLD OUT: A Medusa Moleskine handprinted by the Gutter's own Carol!  A dark green 3.5 x 5.5" pocket Moleskine with a light green Medusa handprinted on the cover. Guaranteed 100% non-petrifying! Declared "quality items. KWALITAY" by author Chlöe Yates!
SOLD OUT: Have a noggin filled with spooky thoughts? Proud of your endoskeletal cranium? Show off either or both this with this beanie / watch cap with a subtle skull pattern in multicolored wool made and donated by Huge Shark! They are knit of black alpaca with multicolored wool. They'll fit from a medium woman's head to a medium man's head. Hand wash/dry flat.
SOLD OUT: Keep your mitts warm with these fingerless owl mittens knit by Huge Shark. They have a secret knit owl pattern on them! Brown tweed (85% wool, 10% silk, 5% cashmere). Sized to fit a large woman to medium-large man's hand. Hand wash/dry flat.
SOLD OUT: A print copy of Meredith Lewis' new book, Ask For The Moon: Innovation at Shaw Brothers Studios! "In the 1960s Shaw Brothers Studios revolutionised martial arts filmmaking. Movie mogul Sir Run Run Shaw developed a way to churn out lavish blockbusters quickly and cheaply. An assembly line approach kept his filmmakers busy but access to an extraordinary pool of resources meant they could 'ask for the moon.' This book is a case study exploring how a brilliant, driven entrepreneur and his audaciously creative filmmakers conducted a bold experiment in business and movie-making innovation."
SOLD OUT: A print copy of Cocktails & Capers: Cult Films, Crime, Cocktails, and Cool by the Gutter's own Keith Allison! "Explore a world populated by masked marvels and murderous maniacs, venomous vamps and gentleman thieves, swingin' spies and cantankerous crooners. Cocktails & Capers collects essays covering cinematic, pop culture, true crime, and cocktail history, including: Sweet Smell of Success and the nightclubs of Swing Street; A.J. Raffles, gentleman thief; Louis Feuillade's Fantomas and Les Vampires; the history of the Martini; Diabolik, Kriminal, and the skeleton suit-clad maniacs of Italy and Turkey; James Bond, amari, negronis, and how Ian Fleming and Lucky Luciano saved the Allied invasion of Sicily; the history of masked Mexican wrestlers and the partnership of El Santo and Blue Demon; and the weird, wild world of the Rat Pack in the 1960s and how the grim, violent Matt Helm novels became slapstick spy spoofs starring Dean Martin. These are tales of mobsters, movie stars, masked men, torch singers, crooners, and hustlers -- with dozens of cocktail recipes and music suggestions that pair perfectly."
SOLD OUT: A digital copy of Dracula In Istanbul, aka, Turkish Dracula, edited by Neon Harbor's Ed Glaser. "For the first time in English comes a remarkable literary discovery. In 1928, Turkish author Ali Rıza Seyfioğlu pirated Bram Stoker’s Dracula, rewriting it with new material, patriotic overtones, and Islam. A rare example of a 'bootleg' novel, it’s also the first adaptation to plainly identify Dracula as the historical warlord Vlad the Impaler."
SOLD OUT: a needle-felted critter from Venus made by friend of the Gutter, Kerry Fristoe. This critter's name is Beulah and she is beautiful! You might recognize the critter from It Conquered The World!
SOLD OUT: A gorgeous horror-themed motivational poster made by Steve Jencks!
If we don't reach our goal, we'll use the funds to print and ship your perks and see how much we can pay each editor. If we exceed our goal, we would use the extra funds to print promotional materials or hire more guest writers. If we significantly exceed our goal, we will use our funds to give the writers a raise this year.
We will be unlocking more perks as the campaign continues, but even $1 gets our Undying Thanks! (Really, a buck does make a difference).
The Impact
We like to think that the Gutter offers something special: Clear-eyed, thoughtful and thought-provoking writing on disreputable art. If you donate or support the campaign by sharing, you will help keep the Gutter online and running; support our particular take on disreputable art; and help support paying writers for their work.
We ran a successful last fundraiser year, and, thanks to everyone's help, we escaped our old webhost, moved to a new webhost, and have been working on making the new Gutter as good as can be. And we kept the Gutter going. The Cultural Gutter's survival depends on Gutterthon and on you. We know it's a difficult time for creators of all kinds, that platforms are valued more than content. But we believe with your help, we can keep the Gutter flowing with quality writing. 
We know that times are hard for a lot of people and any little bit helps, even a retweet or sharing our campaign on Facebook. Indiegogo has tools that make it easy. Please consider using them even if you can't contribute money. Anything you do to help is appreciated.
Thank you from all of us at The Cultural Gutter!

story:
Story of My Book

My Deepest, Darkest Secrets: Tell All Your Friends is a coming of age story that happens in real-time. With raw, untouched excerpts from my diaries, I reflect on the lessons I’m learning while growing up in a messy, chaotic, fascinating, and silly world.

My name is Kelly Wiesehan and I am the author of My Deepest, Darkest Secrets: Tell All Your Friends. I wrote this book because I have diary entries from the last ten years of my life, and it seems unfair to keep these tokens of universal truth to myself. I want to share these intimate thoughts with anyone else who’s in the middle of growing up and wondering what the hell is going on, and doing their best to figure it all out.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover a power to own your mistakes and move forward with a ferocious intention about who you want to be. I want you to see this book as an opportunity to explore the facets of friendship and heartbreak; as an escape from the notion that you have to fit into a mould; to laugh about embarrassing, cringeworthy moments, and learn alongside myself about the importance of reflection, taking risks, intentional relationships, and exploring who you are while you start to claim space in this big world.

In this book, you'll encounter multifaceted dimensions of identity, heartbreak, and friendship through narratives like:

  • Transitioning from a sheltered high school environment to a worldly, diverse university and learning to open my mind to other approaches to life
  • Moving to a new city and ending a long term relationship that forced me to confront my values and priorities
  • Reflecting on past and present friendships and learning what it means to be a good friend and bring wonderful people into my life

You will love this book if you are trying to figure this shit out. And by “shit” I mean: high school, college, friends, boyfriends, parents, God, tequila (in that order), and how to have a good ass time while trying to learn what kind of person you want to be.

My Deepest, Darkest Secrets speaks to young women and people in their early twenties who want to grapple with learning to own their eccentricities and take risks in order to grow in a new way.

Ultimately, I hope that My Deepest, Darkest Secrets inspires reflection and meaningful dialogue, pressing into engaging questions like:

What do we want and how do we go after it with zest and passion?

What behaviors contribute to an intentional, healthy friendship?

How can you recover from heartbreak in an empowering, exploratory way?

I look forward to exploring these questions and beyond with my readers. I believe discussing the importance of reflection, honoring our evolution, and learning to laugh at ourselves will elevate all of our paths.

The Book - My Deepest, Darkest Secrets: Tell All Your Friends

The book is written in 4 parts.

Part 1 contains the author’s note + chapters 1-5. In these chapters, the reader will learn about where I grew up, my lively family dynamic, going to Catholic high school in St. Louis, how I got involved in improv, and my journey to being accepted into a Top 20 university. Part 1 lets readers get to know me and where I come from, and serves as a great foreshadowing to the rest of my story.

Part 2 contains chapters 6-9. These stories explore my transition into college, landing my dream internship at NBC, living in New York City, and the ending of my nearly four year relationship. This part is interesting because while my childhood dreams were coming to fruition, my long-term relationship was slowly and painfully falling apart.

Part 3 contains chapters 10-12. What I find silly about most movies, books, and TV shows is that they usually end with a “happily ever after” or “the break up.” Well, in life, our movie doesn’t stop. We have to keep going. And this part dives into how I’m pulling myself together after a terrible break up with a boyfriend and friends.

Part 4 contains chapters 13-15. The last part brings us seemingly full circle with important lessons I’ve learned, my experience with Covid-19, and wraps up my evolution with an acknowledgment of the growth that has happened over years of journaling about growing up.

 

What I Need & What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:

 

  • The editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in April 2021.
  • The cover design of my book. (The mockups you see currently are a placeholder!)
  • The layout design for the interior of my book (physical copy, ebook formats).
  • The copy editing for my book to polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication.
  • The launch & promotion efforts for my book when I ultimately publish this April.

When I pre-sell 120 copies of my book, I will publish a paperback and ebook. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish a hardcover edition. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover and an audiobook.

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:
  • You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish.
  • Your name will appear in the Acknowledgments section of my book.
  • You will receive early access to the Author’s Note and other excerpts from my book, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback.
  • You will have the opportunity to be involved in selecting my cover and title.
  • You will be invited to join my Author Community and get behind-the-scenes sneak peeks into the publishing process.
  • A discount code to my family’s coffee company, Breve Coffee, because coffee and a good book go very well together!

About the Author


Kelly Wiesehan has small legs, big teeth, a massive personality, and zest for life. She is currently a senior at Washington University in St. Louis and will be graduating this May 2021.

Kelly has been saying she will write a book since the time she could speak. She’s been fervently writing since she was 11, and doing improv comedy since she was 15. She’s passionate about telling good stories, making people laugh, and bringing people together through honest, empathy-driven conversations.

Kelly’s currently living at home with her parents for her senior year of college, which is very ironic considering she always wants to dance and party. She just does that in her childhood bedroom now. In her free time, she impersonates Moira Rose from Schitt’s Creek, listens to French Pop music and pretends to have a niche music taste, asks her friends to play card games at 2 am, and drinks wine and orders random things on Amazon like a gold middle finger statue and an acupuncture kit for your ears. That one was an accident. She is the co-captain of her college improv team, and working very hard towards graduating in May.

For more information, you can connect with Kelly at kelly.wiesehan@gmail.com and follow her on Instagram @kelly.wiesehan.

 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by including the cost of mailing and shipping the signed copies into each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we ship the pre-order rewards to you as early as possible. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as to when my book will publish. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please share my pre-sale campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #smalllegsbigteeth and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press, so we can help amplify your efforts.

You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page.

Please share my book with 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it via text or direct message on social media.

Thank you so much for of all of your love and support!

THANK YOU & PEACE OUT,
Kelly Wiesehan

story:
An Introduction

A friend of mine, Terry Baldwin, contacted me about a young adult novel he had written called Tess, Terrorists and the Tiara. It dealt with prejudice against American Muslims and aimed at a 10-14-year old reader. He had shopped the manuscript around to various publishers and literary agents, but the impression he received was that, if Muslims were going to feature at all in a book for teens, they should be villains and not sympathetic characters.


I read the manuscript, liked it, and agreed to help Terry publish it.


The Project

Tess, Terrorists and the Tiara is a 216 page book about tolerance and the perils of prejudice and fear. Tess is a thirteen-year old girl who has never been able to compete with her “perfect” older sister.  Now she must—if she wants to inherit her grandmother’s priceless tiara.The two girls have been invited to their grandparent’s lake house for the summer to help take care of Grandma who’s been diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease. The sister who earns the most “helpful points” wins the former beauty queen’s crown.â€¨â€¨It’s not easy for Tess, who seems to always get things wrong despite bestâ€¨intentions. But when a secretive family moves in nearby and Grandmaâ€¨disappears, Tess learns a lesson about the real value of doing good—a lesson that may be worth even more than the tiara.


Some advance readers' reviews can be found on amazon.com

The Status

The novel is complete--edited, designed, laid-out, and has an eye-catching cover. We've countless hours contacting young adult book reviewers, as well as printing several paperback review copies for high-profile review journals such as School Library Journal. An extensive social-media campaign has already been started.

The Impact

We all know that one young adult novel can never reach enough readers to have a measurable impact on future world affairs. But if we can help to plant seeds in the minds of as many young people as we are able to reach, we've made a start. And, if I might be perhaps too optimistic, if this book is successful enough, it might inspire larger publishers to accept books with similar messages.


How You Can Help

By purchasing an advance copy of Tess, Terrorists and the Tiara, you can help fund the printing of a hard cover edition, which isneeded if we want to get the book into the hands of school librarians. If you can help spread the word, you can multiply your contribution.

story:
We envision Spry as a literary journal that features undiscovered and established writers' concise, experimental, hybrid, modern, vintage or just plain vulnerable writing. We see this as a place for people who excel at taking risks, who thrive under pressure - for people whose words and rhythms are spry.

Our goal is to raise enough money to host and fund the development of a website that is worthy of featuring the work of the writers who submit to and read Spry. The quoted price of our web development, including hosting and other labors, comes out to $600. We're hoping to raise at least $500 to help us get Spry online, so we can help brilliant writers ignite and inspire in all kinds of ways. To help Spry grow, we want to build it an attractive, easily navigable home -- and to do that, we are hoping for your help. Any help! $1, $5, $50 - if you can spare it, we will be eternally grateful. Even if you can't, just helping us spread the word about Spry would mean so much!

If you're interested in submitting your writing for the first issue of Spry Literary Journal, please visit http://sprylit.submittable.com/submit to review the guidelines and submit your work.

Thanks so much for taking the time to read this and look at our Indiegogo.

Write boldly!

-Erin and Linsey

 

About the editors:

Erin A. Corriveau is an emotional archeologist who just graduated from Fairfield University’s MFA program with a concentration in creative nonfiction. Her writing has been published in Shoreline Literary Arts Magazine. She is the cofounder and chief editor of Spry Literary Journal and writes at her lifestyle blog, Reinventing Erin. She was previously the creative nonfiction editor at Mason's Road Literary Journal. She lives in Massachusetts with her handsome boyfriend, his even cuter son, and their opinionated dog, Fenway.

24 years ago, a sweet-ass jazz dragon collided with a smooth-talking mop creature. The end result was Linsey Jayne, a poet with a Flash jones who received her MFA in creative writing at Fairfield University. She has served as an editor for the Bryant Literary Review and The Archway, and is the cofounder and editor-in-chief of Spry Literary Journal. She is at work on her first collection of poetry, entitled "Idle Jive."

Websites

  • http://sprylit.com
  • http://reinventingerin.com
  • http://masonsroad.com

The quoted price of our web development, including hosting and other labors, comes out to $600. We're hoping to raise at least $500 to help us get Spry online, so we can help brilliant writers ignite and inspire in all kinds of ways. To help Spry grow, we want to build it an attractive, easily navigable home -- and to do that, we are hoping for your help. Any help! $1, $5, $50 - if you can spare it, we will be eternally grateful. Even if you can't, just helping us spread the word about Spry would mean so much!
If you're interested in submitting your writing for the first issue of Spry Literary Journal, please visit http://sprylit.submittable.com/submit to review the guidelines and submit your work.
Thanks so much for taking the time to read this and look at our Indiegogo.
Write boldly!
-Erin and Linsey
 
About the editors:
Erin A. Corriveau is an emotional archeologist who just graduated from Fairfield University’s MFA program with a concentration in creative nonfiction. Her writing has been published in Shoreline Literary Arts Magazine. She is the cofounder and chief editor of Spry Literary Journal and writes at her lifestyle blog, Reinventing Erin. She was previously the creative nonfiction editor at Mason's Road Literary Journal. She lives in Massachusetts with her handsome boyfriend, his even cuter son, and their opinionated dog, Fenway.
24 years ago, a sweet-ass jazz dragon collided with a smooth-talking mop creature. The end result was Linsey Jayne, a poet with a Flash jones who received her MFA in creative writing at Fairfield University. She has served as an editor for the Bryant Literary Review and The Archway, and is the cofounder and editor-in-chief of Spry Literary Journal. She is at work on her first collection of poetry, entitled "Idle Jive."
Websites

http://sprylit.com
http://reinventingerin.com
http://masonsroad.com

story:
Me

Hi, my name’s Natalia! I’m an author of Young Adult/New Adult romance, and this is my second quest for bookish crowdfunding. The last time was terrifying and a total leap of faith, and now here I am, ready to take that leap again!

The Backstory

 

"A fool is a man who believes glory can be found at the tip of a sword instead of on the tip of his tongue. That is life's cruel trick." ~Poet, the Court Jester of Spring

Back in 2015, an Indiegogo campaign helped fund the publication of my novel, TRICK.

The story takes place in a fantasy kingdom, and it’s about the forbidden love between a princess and a court jester. I was astounded and humbled by the response it got from readers, not only toward the love story but also the diverse characters and the representation of mental illness.

It received happy reviews by bloggers including The Artist and the Bookworm, Read Around the Rosie, and Magic-in-Every-Book; it won the November 2015 Goodreads Cover Contest; it was the December 2015 book of the YA Chronicles; and I was interviewed about the novel by Butter My Books and The Shy Books. I cannot express my gratitude for everyone who has supported the story and kept it afloat since then.

Because this is a world of season kingdoms—TRICK is set in the Kingdoms of Spring and Autumn—readers expressed an interest in the rest of this universe. So when the time came to think about my next book, I wondered what the Kingdoms of Summer and Winter would be like.

The New Story

"Love was a danger to all. To the heart. To sanity. Yet all dared to have it." ~Jeryn, the Prince of Winter

Inspiration led to a follow-up of TRICK. It’s called DARE, and it's the second book in what I’ve knighted as the Foolish Kingdoms duology. Same universe, new couple.

In this tale, a coldhearted prince and his maddened prisoner find themselves shipwrecked on a mysterious rainforest island. It’s about isolation and survival, and along the way, some love stuff happens too.

The novel is complete and deep in the editing stage. As of now, my goal is to release it in late July.

The Plot

A Hotheaded Prisoner

They say she's mad—made of madness, made of fire. In a cage by the sea, Flare dreams of escape. She yearns for the day when she'll flee to a place only she knows, a hidden world of mystical waters and gilded sands.

The island is calling to her. And she she won't let anyone keep her from it.

Especially not him.

A Coldhearted Prince

They say he's cruel—crowned of cruelty, as cold as ice. A prince whose gaze cuts like the incisions he administers within his lab. Jeryn has sailed beyond his kingdom for the Trade, to bargain for those wild, imprisoned fools that make his skin crawl.

By law, they're subjects meant for experimentation. And easy to despise.

One in particular. A girl seething at him from behind bars, with burning eyes and ready fists.

A Mythical Shipwreck

But on the cusp of transport, the tide rages. That uncharted island awaits, a dark tangle of foliage where creatures slither in the mist and poisons lurk in the flora.

Stranded, the prince and prisoner must fight to survive. In this mysterious rainforest, they must band together . . . if they don't slay one another first. Or become something more to each other.

Something just as dangerous.

*Mature YA. Intended for readers 17 and older*

The Cover

The talented Nicole Jaffe deserves all the applause for this stunning cover design  & illustration. I cannot be more grateful for her creative dedication to this book and for adding her own magic to it!

Why I’m Here

To see the TRICK campaign become a communal effort and reach its goal from generous contributions warmed my heart. That said, being a writer is a pricey craft, and the amount of coins it requires keeps going up each time. I’m hoping for boost of support for this next tale.

Funding Will Help Pay For

Perk fulfillment, the cover designer, the editor, printing, shipping, and promotion. I’m striving to break even, but if I’m lucky, there might be some spare change to help me keep writing.

Some of the Perks to be Had

*Character magnetic bookmarks (upper) & sticker bookplates (lower). Custom designs and photos by TheWoodsAvenue.

Goal Rewards

At 50% funded: Contributors will get a sneak peek of a scene from my little rainforest novel.

At 75% funded: All smiles, and I’ll do a pre-release video reading of DARE'S prologue.

At 100% funded: Yay, I’ll post a release day video where I’ll answer contributor questions about the Foolish Kingdoms duology.

But if You Can’t Donate

Bookstagram, Booklr, Booktube! Tumblr posts, or tweets, or fan art, or reviews! Spreading the word and the fan love is golden. Word-of-mouth and social media shout-outs go a long way, they make an infinite difference, and they mean so much. Especially for an indie author.

And if You’d Like to Know More

Curl up and have a look at the video. Last time, a ferret kept me company. This time, the torch has been passed to a new sidekick. He’s tiny, green, and has a tendency to ribbet.

Thank you so much!
Natalia

Website
Goodreads
Tumblr
Pinterest

story:
Short Summary

Have you ever been accused of something you didn't do? Of course you have. Was it an accusation that completely changed your life? Were you left doubting your core beliefs? Did you expect to get your life back? I did. I was wrong.

A Teacher's Terror is a true story of just such a situation. It's not a book I want to write. It's a book I need to write. Not just for me, but also for every teacher out there that believes it couldn't happen to them.

This book will chronicle the past three years of my life. It's a true story of deceit, betrayal, apathy, political corruption, and greed. I'll take you to the deepest, darkest parts of my depression and how this has changed forever how I see the world.

I've lost everything. Every resource has been exhausted. Before long, I will lose my home. What I have not lost is my self-respect and the knowledge that I’ve done nothing wrong and the comfort of supporting friends and family. So I've decided it’s time to tell my story publicly. But I need your help.

The book will have to be self-published. But it needs to be published. The publishing fees and associated costs start at about $3000, so that's my goal - to raise enough for a first printing.

Has a teacher made a difference in your life? You couldn't read this if one hadn't. Remember that teacher when you're considering contributing to this campaign. I MIGHT BE THAT TEACHER.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!

story:
要旨だね (Short Summary)

Hi, I'm Matthew Rowe. I've been working as a teacher for 5 years, and I'm in my 4th year here in Japan. I’m also an independent author with two highly praised books available in stores. The great thing about that is that I made them myself, from scratch. I even chopped down the trees and jumped up and down on them until they turned into pulp to make the paper. No really, I can show you the residue on my boots!

I tasked my 2nd grade students with the goal of writing reviews of their favourite parts of Japanese culture to put into a book and publish it. The difficult part being, it’s in English! Despite the usual initial shock and a bonus smattering of disbelief that the book would be published at all, they have performed wonderfully. Their reviews are finished and raring to go. I just have to format them into a handy book shape, with an aim to release the book in January.

Not only that but I told them, and it is no lie, that all profits will go to help local victims of last year’s earthquake who are still rebuilding their lives.

I gave my second grade high schoolers this project, with it's lofty goals, for so many reasons.

  1. I wanted to use my expertise in lessons to do something no one else could do.
  2. Something different for the students is something fun, and they seriously need fun!
  3. Students get to write about something they are passionate about.
  4. They can help people all over the world learn about their country.
  5. They can show the school and the Board of Education that it’s okay to try something different (or rather, I can! Mwuahahaha!).
  6. They can help local earthquake victims with the profits they make from the book.
  7. They can see that even a learner's English can have a big impact.
  8. They get to work together to produce a tangible record (and great memory) of their achievement to treasure for the rest of their lives.

This book can do so much, but only if it is seen and read by many people. So, that’s where you come in. Your small contribution could bring a smile, confidence, better education and improved quality of life for people here in Japan..

 

 

ほしいものは? (What We Need)

So where will our money go? Well, we are asking for $1,999 USD. It's a nice psychological trick to make people go "oh, it's less than $2,000!"

This is what it will be used for:

  • Printing costs: It's $3 a book and we want an initial run of 500 books! So that's $1,500 already! ふっふ～
  • Global Distribution: $100
  • Shipping to Japan:$3 a book. So another $1,500, because we have to get our hands on the books to be able to sign them for you! And to give to local schools, etc.
  • Cover Illustration: $200 because it’s darn good.
  • Indiegogo fees: 4% if we meet our goal, 9% if we don't.
  • Apologetic meal for my girlfriend, for spending so much time working on this project and not with her: $50

TOTAL ＝$3,350 + fees

We are going to do our best to contribute ourselves of course, but the school isn't rich and neither am I. So here we are asking for your help towards this. We're aiming to pay for initial shipping costs (and I'll pay for my girlfriend's meal of course!) but the printing costs will come directly out of our profit.

We want to give as much as possible to charity, so if we reach our goal, we can have a strong initial run and kickstart our charity effort. If we fail, then this will be just another writing exercise for the students, but we can order a few copies of the book in a slow trickle. However, we won't be able to gift books to the local community, students who contributed and backers. So the project will lose most of its impact! It would be like Godzilla if he were suddenly the size of a real lizard. At least the book will be out there! 

Should the kami-sama (gods) smile on us and we raise above our target, that money will go directly to our charity and the local people who need it. It will rebuild houses, shops and communities. It will buy school supplies. It will pay for repairs and the ongoing clean-up operation. It will get long suffering peoples’ lives back to normal.

 

プレゼントを上げるよ！　What You Get

What? Satisfaction that you are helping to change the world, improve lives and rescue the needy isn't enough for you? Don't worry. I am just playing with you. I know how important this is and we are all super grateful that you would even look at this page (or consider tweeting about it? Hint! Hint!) so anyone who contributes actual, real, honest spendable cash will receive some lovely thank you gifts that I hope express the depths of our thanks.

All backers will get their name listed in a special ‘Thank You’ section of the book, but you could also get an exclusive e-book version of the final product with bonus illustrations, personal thank you cards from students, signed copies of the book, original, one of a kind pictures drawn for the book by students, the chance to include your own illustrations in the final print and....well, I can’t promise anything but I would just love to offer a personal, expenses paid tour of Sendai city and our school (flight and hotel paid for, that is), but that could only happen if someone backed us way beyond our target!... ahem. What was that? Oh I said nothing.

 

インパクト! The Impact

Living and working in Japan is crazy, fun and sometimes really frustrating. Do you remember in school when you had those lessons where the teacher just droned on and on? "Bueller? Anyone? Anyone?" It was about a boring subject, and all the students could do was try and stay awake long enough to write down some notes that might be important in the test later on. You know the type. We've all been there. Well, Japanese lessons are like that all the time. The teacher speaks, students fill in blanks on a worksheet. Lesson ends! There’s no fun! There’s no creativity! There’s no will to live!

Then along comes gangly, slightly nutty, but not harmful to your allergies, me and I bring some fun activities for my students to do and they stare at them like they are nuns in a roadies bar. Poor souls. They’ve forgotten what it’s like to... um… what was I talking about?

The students in Japan are in so much trouble and they don't even know it. They don't know how to express themselves, they don't know how to think creatively, they don't have any break from the pressure placed upon them by society and their parents at their school, they don't have any fun and they certainly don't have any confidence!

Also, as I am sure you are aware, last year, Japan suffered a terrible disaster of earthquake, tsunami and nuclear meltdown. I was here. It was a terrifying time for everybody. Just 3km from our school, everything was swept away. Tens of thousands of people lost their lives and hundreds of thousands have lost everything else. Loved ones have died or been injured, homes have been destroyed, jobs lost and with it any safety and security for the future.

The disaster disappeared from the news in a few days, but over 18 months later, here in Japan it's still a huge part of peoples' lives. Many still live in temporary homes after long periods being homeless or sheltering in school halls; towns are barren; schools are just starting to stock all their needed supplies; and no one knows what effect the radiation will have in the future... 

In short, there are many people who still need help. My students know this because they are all, at the very least, familiar with someone who has lost so much. So, I suggested that money raised from our project, the sale of this book, be donated to help local people recover from the disaster.

If you help us reach our goal we can achieve all this and so much more. The book is already written. It just needs some editing and it is ready to go to the printers. However, the self publishing service is a strange concept here in Japan, so local printing is out of the question. We want to use Amazon's Createspace service to publish our book as it would also give us better exposure. With your money, we can get an initial run of books to students, local schools, libraries and you, the backers. So then, word of our project can spread.

The more people who know about our project and its huge success, the more good we can do. Money raised will help disaster victims on their way; the success will show the Board of Education that we know what we are doing, teachers will gain confidence and try new ideas and bigger projects with even greater benefits, but most of all the students will gain some confidence in their English and in themselves, because right now, they have no idea that their imperfect English could do anything except cause embarrassment.

Photo (right) ©23hours, two boys play in the cramped conditions of temporary housing in Miyagi prefecture.

It's not just the students though, the teachers too need confidence in their abilities and confidence that anything other than the tried and tested (and worn out and flogged and neighing in its death throes style) lesson plans can work.

In short; Japanese people live in a box. I live outside the box. I want to show them its ok outside the box, but here's this nice idea that will give them some money to make their box a little better in the meantime.

(No more boxes! Revolution!)

Now, I know what you are thinking; “He’s probably going to edit the work into a shiny piece of perfection!” but the truth is I’m not. My students really are that good. The work will be published warts and all for you to read and learn from. As a bonus, for comparisons sake, I’m including my own article and I am sure you will see the difference.

How can you trust me?

Well, let’s think about the alternative, shall we? If I edit all the mistakes in their work and turn it into a perfectly publishable book (by normal standards), can you imagine how the students would feel? “That’s not my work!” will be their first thought. Disappointment, disenchantment, anger and retreat will set in. Hitler will march over all of Europe and there will be no one to stop him! Sorry, got sidetracked. They will lose confidence, not gain it and the main purpose of this project will be lost. Not to mention all the work I would have to do for that. Where as if I publish their work with mistakes, sure, they may be a little embarrassed at first, but when they see what their book achieves and how it affects lives, I think they will feel far happier than embarrassed..

 

ごめんなさい！お金なし！どうする？Other Ways You Can Help

As much as you may be interested in this project, I know some of you will be unable to give help in a monetary form. Yet there is still plenty you can do. For starters, there are many people out there who can give money, but don’t know about the project yet! So tell them!

Here are the links you need:

l  Our Blog: http://machuusensei.wordpress.com With all the information you need on the project, regular progress reports, announcements, and chances to contribute from conception of the idea to its world shattering success (and the subsequent gluing back together of said world because we are trying to fix things really)

l  Facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/letspopculture With updates
in snippet form and photos. Easily share the project with friends and family

 

 

l  IndieGoGo page: http://www.indiegogo.com/letspopculture That’s the page you are looking at now and the only one you can donate money through. So if you like it, share!

Get these links sailing across the net onto all the pages of friends, families and strangers; those who love Japan and those who can’t resist a charity effort! You can tweet, tumblr, facebook share, weibo, tivo, pancake, fry base, oven cook or just plain microwave at 500w for 15 minutes.

 

どうもありがとうございます！Thank you very much!

We honestly want to express a huge thank you to everyone who looks at this page, not just the contributors who will help to change lives, but even those amongst you who only send a tweet, because really that simple action could net us a hundred more contributors and start a chain reaction of awesomeness that has the universe explode in ecstasy. You can’t prove me wrong, but you can try, I dare you.

 

Not forgetting another massive hug from 3 little English teachers and 200 cutsie-wutsie Japanese high school students to Indiegogo. We couldn’t do a thing without them. They are making our little dream into a towering world-saving monstrosity, a bit like a Godzilla in a Florence Nightingale outfit. Too weird? Well, this is Japan!

 

Thank you so much!

I know how important this is and we are all super grateful that you would even look at this page (or consider tweeting about it? Hint! Hint!) so anyone who contributes actual, real, honest spendable cash will receive some lovely thank you gifts that I hope express the depths of our thanks.
All backers will get their name listed in a special ‘Thank You’ section of the book, but you could also get an exclusive e-book version of the final product with bonus illustrations, personal thank you cards from students, signed copies of the book, original, one of a kind pictures drawn for the book by students, the chance to include your own illustrations in the final print and....well, I can’t promise anything but I would just love to offer a personal, expenses paid tour of Sendai city and our school (flight and hotel paid for, that is), but that could only happen if someone backed us way beyond our target!... ahem. What was that? Oh I said nothing.
 
インパクト! The Impact
Living and working in Japan is crazy, fun and sometimes really frustrating. Do you remember in school when you had those lessons where the teacher just droned on and on? "Bueller? Anyone? Anyone?" It was about a boring subject, and all the students could do was try and stay awake long enough to write down some notes that might be important in the test later on. You know the type. We've all been there. Well, Japanese lessons are like that all the time. The teacher speaks, students fill in blanks on a worksheet. Lesson ends! There’s no fun! There’s no creativity! There’s no will to live!
Then along comes gangly, slightly nutty, but not harmful to your allergies, me and I bring some fun activities for my students to do and they stare at them like they are nuns in a roadies bar. Poor souls. They’ve forgotten what it’s like to... um… what was I talking about?

The students in Japan are in so much trouble and they don't even know it. They don't know how to express themselves, they don't know how to think creatively, they don't have any break from the pressure placed upon them by society and their parents at their school, they don't have any fun and they certainly don't have any confidence!
Also, as I am sure you are aware, last year, Japan suffered a terrible disaster of earthquake, tsunami and nuclear meltdown. I was here. It was a terrifying time for everybody. Just 3km from our school, everything was swept away. Tens of thousands of people lost their lives and hundreds of thousands have lost everything else. Loved ones have died or been injured, homes have been destroyed, jobs lost and with it any safety and security for the future.

The disaster disappeared from the news in a few days, but over 18 months later, here in Japan it's still a huge part of peoples' lives. Many still live in temporary homes after long periods being homeless or sheltering in school halls; towns are barren; schools are just starting to stock all their needed supplies; and no one knows what effect the radiation will have in the future... 
In short, there are many people who still need help. My students know this because they are all, at the very least, familiar with someone who has lost so much. So, I suggested that money raised from our project, the sale of this book, be donated to help local people recover from the disaster.
If you help us reach our goal we can achieve all this and so much more. The book is already written. It just needs some editing and it is ready to go to the printers. However, the self publishing service is a strange concept here in Japan, so local printing is out of the question. We want to use Amazon's Createspace service to publish our book as it would also give us better exposure. With your money, we can get an initial run of books to students, local schools, libraries and you, the backers. So then, word of our project can spread.

The more people who know about our project and its huge success, the more good we can do. Money raised will help disaster victims on their way; the success will show the Board of Education that we know what we are doing, teachers will gain confidence and try new ideas and bigger projects with even greater benefits, but most of all the students will gain some confidence in their English and in themselves, because right now, they have no idea that their imperfect English could do anything except cause embarrassment.
Photo (right) ©23hours, two boys play in the cramped conditions of temporary housing in Miyagi prefecture.
It's not just the students though, the teachers too need confidence in their abilities and confidence that anything other than the tried and tested (and worn out and flogged and neighing in its death throes style) lesson plans can work.
In short; Japanese people live in a box. I live outside the box. I want to show them its ok outside the box, but here's this nice idea that will give them some money to make their box a little better in the meantime.
(No more boxes! Revolution!)
Now, I know what you are thinking; “He’s probably going to edit the work into a shiny piece of perfection!” but the truth is I’m not. My students really are that good. The work will be published warts and all for you to read and learn from. As a bonus, for comparisons sake, I’m including my own article and I am sure you will see the difference.
How can you trust me?
Well, let’s think about the alternative, shall we? If I edit all the mistakes in their work and turn it into a perfectly publishable book (by normal standards), can you imagine how the students would feel? “That’s not my work!” will be their first thought. Disappointment, disenchantment, anger and retreat will set in. Hitler will march over all of Europe and there will be no one to stop him! Sorry, got sidetracked. They will lose confidence, not gain it and the main purpose of this project will be lost. Not to mention all the work I would have to do for that. Where as if I publish their work with mistakes, sure, they may be a little embarrassed at first, but when they see what their book achieves and how it affects lives, I think they will feel far happier than embarrassed..
 
ごめんなさい！お金なし！どうする？Other Ways You Can Help
As much as you may be interested in this project, I know some of you will be unable to give help in a monetary form. Yet there is still plenty you can do. For starters, there are many people out there who can give money, but don’t know about the project yet! So tell them!
Here are the links you need:
l  Our Blog: http://machuusensei.wordpress.com With all the information you need on the project, regular progress reports, announcements, and chances to contribute from conception of the idea to its world shattering success (and the subsequent gluing back together of said world because we are trying to fix things really)
l  Facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/letspopculture With updates in snippet form and photos. Easily share the project with friends and family
 
 
l  IndieGoGo page: http://www.indiegogo.com/letspopculture That’s the page you are looking at now and the only one you can donate money through. So if you like it, share!
Get these links sailing across the net onto all the pages of friends, families and strangers; those who love Japan and those who can’t resist a charity effort! You can tweet, tumblr, facebook share, weibo, tivo, pancake, fry base, oven cook or just plain microwave at 500w for 15 minutes.
 
どうもありがとうございます！Thank you very much!
We honestly want to express a huge thank you to everyone who looks at this page, not just the contributors who will help to change lives, but even those amongst you who only send a tweet, because really that simple action could net us a hundred more contributors and start a chain reaction of awesomeness that has the universe explode in ecstasy. You can’t prove me wrong, but you can try, I dare you.
 
Not forgetting another massive hug from 3 little English teachers and 200 cutsie-wutsie Japanese high school students to Indiegogo. We couldn’t do a thing without them. They are making our little dream into a towering world-saving monstrosity, a bit like a Godzilla in a Florence Nightingale outfit. Too weird? Well, this is Japan!
 
Thank you so much!

story:
Our Story

Our goal is to raise $10,000 in 10 weeks to facilitate the printing of Khadijah and the Mirror. We want to spread the message of self confidence and empowerment to children everywhere, giving them permission to be who they are as they are.


The Impact

Johnnett Kent, a former educator, saw firsthand how children are trying to find how they fit into this world. Khadijah was inspired by the ideal that children need to value themselves in order to become productive members of society.  

What We Need & What You Get

All proceeds go to the publishing and printing Khadijah and The Mirror. We are looking to raise $10,000 in 10 weeks. Every donation from $1+ will receive a personalized message from Khadijah. A donation of $30+ will receive a signed copy of the book. $100+ receive both a signed copy of the book and a poster. Donations of $500 and up will receive a signed copy of the book, an audio book and a poster.    


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about Khadijah! Check out our site and tell us what you think! We look forward to your feedback.

story:
Shangaan Ethnic Construction    

       I decided to focus on the Hlanganani region of Northern South Africa in my 25 page paper final paper for Amherst Professor Sean Redding’s class “Riot and Rebellion in Pre and Postcolonial Africa,” in particular on Shirley village where I was born. My aim was to prove that the minority Shangaan people were as involved in the anti-Apartheid struggle as the larger ethnic groups. What I found was that very little has been written about the area or its people[1]. But I was determined and I began to interview my family members about the years building up to independence in 1994. What I discovered shifted all of my original premises. Shangaan people are relatively recent immigrants into the country. Their ethnic identity was formed by the Swiss missionaries’ obsession with grouping territorially and, later, by the Apartheid government’s version of ‘divide and conquer.’ It was then manipulated by puppet African leaders to appeal to and unite their Bantustan subjects during the Apartheid era which is why it appealed most to the scattered, newly-arrived Shangaans.

 

A dying history

                    This story is excluded from the official history of mass allegiance with the ANC, however it matches with what scholars such as Isak Neihaus have written about other ethnic groups in rural Transvaal. Ethnic construction is the story of South Africa and Shangaan identity demonstrates it clearly. Writers like Mahmood Mamdhani discuss the Shangaan experience briefly when discussing the broader South African context but their story remains untold because the rural region has remained poor and has not produced any noted historians and scholars. This is why I want to go back this summer to interview the Shangaan people of Hlangani before they are written out of history. I will spend three months doing cultural and life history interviews with various villagers. I hope to achieve triangulation by interviewing people with varying perspectives on and roles in the anti-apartheid movement in order to get as full a picture of the area’s struggle as possible. I will then compare and contrast my findings with those of historians and sociologists to assemble a rural version of the South African liberation struggle[2]  and then make links to how it affects the region today.            

The big picture...

          This research is integral for my proposed self-designed major called African Solutions, the final product of which will be a blueprint for the grassroots development organization that I intend to start after I graduate and return to Shirley Village. And I will publish and archive my findings. Since my reputation as a poet is growing steadily, I will write and film a series of poems about my observations while I am there. These will be shared throughout the semester to conscientize my campus. On a personal level the trip will help me find out more about my identity and assess whether my post-college plan is feasible. The research and observation will help me to understand the form and the roots of the area’s grievances in order to find solutions; local, sustainable, African solutions.

(While I’m there I will be interning with the Legal Resources Center which works on land rights in the area.)


[1] Patrick Harries’ study of Shangaan ethnicity does not go past the 70’s.

[2] Similar to Belinda Bozzoli’s history of former homeland Bophutswana which was constructed from the life histories of elderly women in “Women of Phokeng”

story:
Short Summary

Maranatha Christfestival is a platform set to promote all upcoming PURE Gospel artists.

This concert is a yearly event and this year marks the fourth edition of it, to the glory of God.

The main objective is to win SOULS, Evangelizing through songs ministrations. Secondly, it is a way of bringing together all Christ lovers  to praise the most high, as it is written that 'God inhabit in the praises of his people'. More so, a way to encourage all the artists that going into venture with God is more rewarding and profitable.

They (the acts) touches souls through their songs regardless of their genre, getting people inebriated under the anointing bestowed upon them. For without FAITH we can not please GOD. So, one key thing anyone coming to this great concert has to bring along, outside, the' Palm balm and dancing shoes' is his or her FAITH! and they should come expecting, because to every vision their is a provision.

What We Need & What You Get

I need support in getting next years live concert a reality , as it will be five years old, want it seen and heard in every home, Churches and around the world.

You can partner with this vision  and be a Life/world changer by supporting me financially. My target is $10,000 to drive an incredible media campaign and create more awareness in support of this and to cover costs of this soul winning concert (Flights, Accommodation, Instruments and refreshments). 

Every one that supports us becomes a partner. Partners  according to your kind donation level receive limited edition T-shirts,Maranatha Christfest souvenirs, free items from our freebies stand and names listed in our Eternal book of Fellowship  and more. 

The Impact

Maranatha Christfest started four years ago with the simple vision of winning souls for Christ. Amongst all odds it came to reality with the support of my Church (Mountain of Fire and Miracles Ministries). It was first of it kind in the city of Edinburgh, with a great number of attendees. It is my dream and i would love to keep the fire burning, though not very easy being a single Mum!

Going by the vision, many artists that have been on this platform have been experiencing God move in their lives positively. Testimonies still abounds as many have been nominated for awards @ BEFTA, SCOTTISH AWARDS and more. The likes El Mafrex, Dolly P and Michael Pounds.  

The existence and magnitude of this programme has helped these and many more Gospel artists getting recognition due to the promotions and awareness given to this great concert.

Other Ways You Can Help

We always want media support, you can follow us on Twitter @Sophiefey @newtrendsentertainmentuk or link me up to media bodies with a like mind for more support.
