story:
I want to thank all who have contributed so far! You are my light and grace in this world. 

Special appreciation goes out to the following people who have expressed their generosity in so many ways.

Leandra Ortiz

Ramon Costilla

Tio Daniel and Tia Cynthia

Yolanda Garza

Kevin and Norma Belsole

Rudolfo Guerra

Joe and Ellie Aguirre

My Parents and other friends and family who have given me the ineffable, undeniably beautiful, and spectacularly brilliant little things that mean everything in my writing.

Epiphanies are more subtle than we realize!

The night it struck me, I was sitting on my patio with Roberto Bolano’s 2666 folded over my lap. The cicadas from beyond the mesquites that ensconced my yard slowly began to call in their disconnected chirps until they found each other and harmonized in a tangle of abrasive little bellows that rose and fell like city sirens. As I continued to read, a subtle a wave of recognition entered my thoughts—barely perceptible at first, more akin to awareness than any tangible idea. It gradually matured from a hint of suggestion into palpable understanding. Questions began to formulate. What truly is literature? What is the basis for a masterpiece?  What is the inextricable relationship between reader and author? I became fascinated by the tenuous bonds of literary understanding, reinforced each time a person opened a book and continued to turn the page.

 My epiphany was the subtle recognition in the potential power of literature. It wasn't the kind of dumbfounding moment where the heavens open up as the sun cuts through the sky, pushing through the clouds of uncertainty. It was much more modest and easily missed. A piqued interest moved me to seek out additional works. I began a personal journey, blindly navigating the literary landscape. Unguided, I stumbled through the great works, fumbling for knowledge. Moved by Hugo’s detailed characterizations, Tolstoy’s epic historical landscapes, and Hemingway’s penchant for brevity and subtext, I decided to pursue scholarship formally. 

Inspired but what did I do about it?

Those of you close to me know that I am currently enrolled in a graduate English Studies program at the University of Texas at Brownsville. My intent has been to expose myself to as many stories and styles of writing as possible. 

I have been on a journey. Writing and exploring the stories that are close to me, my family, and the region where I live. I have found that there is a voice within me that resonates in the words I cobble together out of my imagination and personal experience. I am a native Texan, third generation Mexican-American, father, husband, son, grandson, and friend who is marked  by the indelible connections between love, family and culture.

Cano the fiction writer!?!?

I have dedicated the last year to fine tuning my skills and developing stories. It has been a personal goal to reach the point where my work can be considered a serious offering. 

In pursuing opportunities to share my work I became aware of VONA Voices,http://www.voicesatvona.org/ an esteemed program hosted at UC Berkeley. 

The annual workshop is a competitive program where writers from across the country apply for the opportunity to work with some of the most talented authors active today. This year there were a record number of applicants and I was selected as one of about 10 fiction writers from a pool of nearly 1000 hopeful contributors.  My class will be led by Junot Diaz, a Pulitzer Prize winning author, whose most recent work This is How You Lose Her  was a finalist for the National Book Award in 2013. 

http://www.junotdiaz.com/

It is both humbling and exciting to know that my work was accepted.

I see this workshop as an opportunity to further sharpen my skills and refine my work for publication. My intention is to publish so that I may share the stories that have moved me. Sometimes they tickle, some times they knock me on my ass, but they always move me. 

You can see some of my recent efforts here:

http://canocostilla.wordpress.com

Why I need help...

The breakdown:

  • The Workshop costs $800 and there are travel costs associated with reaching California from Texas. In addition I need to pay my own accommodations and meals. I expect I will need about $2000 to attend the workshop which runs from Sunday June 22 to Sunday June 29th. I am only asking for assistance with the fee associated with the program, but any contribution beyond the funding goal will be applied to the additional costs related to the trip.
  • I have included a few perks. You can get advanced copies of my work as well as a signed manuscript of the work I produce as a result of the program.
  • If I don't reach the entire goal, the funds raised will be applied to the costs associated with the conference.

Thanks

Your consideration and contributions would mean a-lot to me personally. Thank You. Thank You. Thank You. 

I feel that with the support of my friends, family and community I am more than a man who writes stories. I am a voice and I will carry you all with me to California. These stories which I hold so dear, in a sense, become yours, because it was through you that they were realized.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute or have contributed already then I just ask that you share with your friends and family. 

You can help get the word out and make some noise about my campaign using the Indiegogo share tools to link to your preferred social media accounts. 

Thanks again

Cano

I have included a few perks. You can get advanced copies of my work as well as a signed manuscript of the work I produce as a result of the program.
If I don't reach the entire goal, the funds raised will be applied to the costs associated with the conference.
ThanksYour consideration and contributions would mean a-lot to me personally. Thank You. Thank You. Thank You. I feel that with the support of my friends, family and community I am more than a man who writes stories. I am a voice and I will carry you all with me to California. These stories which I hold so dear, in a sense, become yours, because it was through you that they were realized.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't contribute or have contributed already then I just ask that you share with your friends and family. You can help get the word out and make some noise about my campaign using the Indiegogo share tools to link to your preferred social media accounts. Thanks againCano

story: I have finally bit the bullet and created an IndieGoGo campaign to help me raise the funds to launch my first book "FUKT 2 START WITH : Short Stories & Broken Werd" with a book launch/signing & accompanying photography show at The Walter Maciel Galley on July 14th in Los Angeles. The funds will be used for my transportaion, shelter, printing of books/artwork, invitations and promotional items for the opening. I can't do this on my own and would deeply appreciate any help my friends can offer. I'm offering some very correct perks, from signed prints & books to a 1 on 1 photo session with me as well as 2 of my diary/trip books from the early 90's. If you believe in me, my book and my art, please take a second to check out my campaign and help me take my dream to this the next level. Much love, light and correctness to each & everyone of you xxWalt
story_txt: I have finally bit the bullet and created an IndieGoGo campaign to help me raise the funds to launch my first book "FUKT 2 START WITH : Short Stories & Broken Werd" with a book launch/signing & accompanying photography show at The Walter Maciel Galley on July 14th in Los Angeles. The funds will be used for my transportaion, shelter, printing of books/artwork, invitations and promotional items for the opening. I can't do this on my own and would deeply appreciate any help my friends can offer. I'm offering some very correct perks, from signed prints & books to a 1 on 1 photo session with me as well as 2 of my diary/trip books from the early 90's. If you believe in me, my book and my art, please take a second to check out my campaign and help me take my dream to this the next level. Much love, light and correctness to each & everyone of you xxWalt

story:
Is Historical Repetition Imminent in Symbolic Iceland?

In the weeks and months that followed Iceland's catastrophic economic collapse in 2008, commentators noted that Reykjavik was something of a "Canary in the Coalmine." Iceland's rapid banking implosion, they posited, made the country something of a crystal ball. Icelanders would feel the effects of the global recession faster and harder than any other country. What transpired in Iceland, they said, could be expected in much of the rest of the world shorly thereafter.

No one could have predicted it at the time, but things didn't really pan out this way. Pain is felt in Iceland, to be sure, but crisis stricken countries elsewhere ended up falling much harder. 

What made the "Canary" observation astute, however, were political events that unfolded in the weeks following the collapse. Icelanders turned out in impressive numbers to protest the corruption, lies, and outright theft that led to them to the brink. In a sense, this foreshadowed the Occupy Movement and the anti-austerity movements that have gripped Athens, Madrid and other European cities since 2008.

In post-collapse Reykjavik, citizens surrounded the Althingi, Iceland's parliament, banging on pots and pans, demanding the resignation of the right wing government that had cheered as bankers ran rampant. The "Kitchenware Revolution" succeeded in the short term, bringing down the Independence Party -- a powerful, long-ruling Reagan/Thatcher fan club that oversaw vast privatizations. Thirty years of unapologetic neoliberal boosterism came to a grinding halt. An election followed, with protesters turned politicians winning seats in the legislature and left of center parties taking the reins of state. 

It was an exciting time to have a dissenting voice in Iceland. Systemic economic changes proved somewhat difficult -- some would argue unnecessary -- but the country played host to a groundbreaking media/transparency reform movement. WikiLeaks activists were in Reykjavik to promote the idea, when a still relatively unknown Julian Assange obtained explosive U.S. government secrets from Bradley Manning. And a reform movement, using innovative techniques, drafted a constitution that would have significantly empowered the electorate. Things looked different. Around the world, whether deserved or not, Iceland earned a reputation as something of a brave, rebellious, nation.

But now, just as conservative (and reactionary) voices have remained relevant elsewhere despite the abject failure of the ideology they espouse, the momentum of those pushing alternative paradigms has slowed in Iceland. The move to rewrite the constitution hit a major snag -- the Althingi failed to approve the document's draft at a crucial moment. And an election scheduled for April 27th appears likely to usher in a return to power for politicians close to those that helped bring Iceland to near ruination.

So what will happen after Icelanders decide their future on the 27th? How can the election's outcome be explained? How will commentators there be reacting to the results? What will Icelanders expect in the election's aftermath? What will become of the spirit of the "Kitchenware Revolution"? How will the canary sing this time around? This is what I hope to find out, straight from the horse's mouth -- on the ground in Reykjavik at the end of the month,

Why me?

I am familiar with the situation in Iceland, as I have been writing about the aftermath of the financial collapse there for over three years.  I have written nine feature length pieces on the subject -- my last one, a 5,000+ word article for Truthout, was "liked" over 4,400 times on Facebook.

I will leverage my contacts to get an insider's look at what is happening, and will interview countless people to get a feel for the zeitgeist. I will talk to experts -- economists, political scientists, local journalists -- and will explore the root causes of the election's outcome. 

What are you paying for?

I can assure you that I will be doing this on a shoestring budget. Your donations will pay for airfare, expenses while I'm there (I'll be staying on friend's couches), and for general living expenses in Washington -- I will spend a significant amount of time on this project, much longer than the week or so I will spend in Iceland. I will be doing prep work before the trip -- research, writing, trying to schedule interviews. And in addition to articles I will publish on the election (I already have interest from one editor), I will be writing an ebook about what happened between 2008 and now -- what became of the Spirit of the Kitchenware Revolution?

So you aren't just donating money to fund a trip -- you're also reserving an advance copy of this book by helping finance this endeavor.

story:
A Summary

Greetings all, my name is Omar Tyree, a New York Times bestselling and award-winning author. I first became known in my hometown of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, as well as in Washington, DC, Baltimore, Maryland and in New York City as a celebrated writer of contemporary urban fiction. After self-publishing my first three books at age 23, 24 and 25 in the early 1990s, I went on to publish 14 straight novels with the publishing house of Simon & Schuster from 1995 to 2008, selling more two million copies worldwide.

However, the publishing industry has changed drastically since the 1990s and early 2000s, and so has my writing. Many national bookstores have closed down, while ebook technology has opened up. And after publishing more than a dozen urban American stories; including Flyy Girl, A Do Right Man, For The Love of Money, Just Say No! and The Last Street Novel—all listed at OmarTyree.com—I realized that there was a much bigger world out there to write impactful stories about and other ways to introduce those stories to thousands of readers.

So I created the Ebook Nation, where writers with big ideas, including novelists, filmmakers and playwrites could all present their work—as originally conceived—with an innovative business approach of celebrity marketing participation. In other words, if you have a great book or film idea with superstars like, Brad Pitt or Will Smith in mind for lead characters—and your story ideas are good enough—the Ebook Nation will professionally edit, publish and market them, while offering a participation agreement to Brad Pitt or Will Smith to help market and promote the ebooks as well as to acquire the film rights. So the bigger the ideas with international stars and reach, the better.

This is the Ebook Nation, a whole new way of creating, publishing and marketing great new stories. And with your small but monumental help, we could all kickoff 2014 with the explosive bang of New Year’s Eve energy!

What Is Needed?

In the industry of publishing, original ebooks are nowhere near as expensive as print. In the old-school print model, supplying a thousand books for a thousand readers would cost thousands of dollars. But in the new-school era of ebooks, there is no printing cost at all. Readers are able to download their desired list of books to ebook reading devices, cutting out the cost of printing, packaging and shipping entirely. Not to mention the cost of warehouse or storage space.

However, there are still costs involved in hiring professional editors to help improve the content. There is no shortcutting the editing process if a publisher desires to produce quality work. There are also costs involved in graphic art design and photography for great, eye-popping cover jackets, as well as costs involved in online marketing to promote the work.

So we calculated a very small, start-up budget of $20,000 which would allow us to employ several quality editors, several innovative graphic designers and key online marketing experts. Once thousands of ebook readers grow to love our books, our brand, our website and our upcoming list of new titles at EbookNationInc.com, the company would quickly capitalize itself in the absence of expensive overheads.

What Is The Impact?

Ultimately, the impact of the Ebook Nation Inc. company will be all about the books and the execution of our innovative model. Presently, we have started the Fall 2013 launch with four Omar Tyree novels, including “The Traveler” series as a new-wave “James Bond” vehicle and an international thriller. The Fast & The Furious film star, Paul Walker, won our reader survey at TheTravelerBooks.com last year. The majority of our readers viewed Paul Walker as an ideal lead for international hero “Gary Stevens” in the No Turning Back prequel as well as the upcoming Welcome to Dubai to be published in December.

In November, the Ebook Nation launches The Sneaker Kings, developed as a perfect, feature film vehicle for young music icon, Justin Bieber. In September, Psychadelic, a music-inspired road comedy film idea—with several musician cameos in mind, including rapper/actor Common—was novelized and released as an ebook. The title is presently for sale for all ebook devices and agreements remain open for celebrity participation in marketing as well as for film rigts.

With 25 published books in 21 years, including six original ebooks and more titles in the works, I am very qualified to run a successful publishing company. I’ve earned 21 years of publishing known-how. We now look forward to a small helping hand of start-up capital to enable us to publish five to six ebooks a month, with great book and film ideas from you.

How Can You Help Us?

First, I want to thank you all for listening, reading and considering your fine contributions. But please take a look at EbookNationInc.com to review the execution of our model as it continues to grow. With new authors who bring explosive new story ideas in the year 2014 and beyond, the company is certain to be successful for years to come. So if you cannot contribute to our campaign at this time, feel free to buy an ebook, leave a great review, buy a Kindle device or submit a brilliant story idea of your own.

The Ebook Nation. Wake up! We just found a loophole in the Matrix! So spread the word!

story:
My Blood Spills

What if someone who knew little about vampires but lots about writing wrote a modern novel about the creatures—one actually? This funding campaign is a humble request: To help raise seed money so I can produce a genre-resetting book about undead set against the modern plague of our times.

Synopsis: An AIDs-like disease spreads across London and Paris. Victims' immunity collapses within 24 hours, sending them into a near-death, comatose state. Searching for causes, a 22 year-old graduate student makes the startling discovery: Patient Zero's DNA places his origins in Northern Europe nearly 700 years ago.

A vampire spreads the disease, which afflicts him as well. However, his system resists hemoglobin, essentially immunity increases, interfering with nourishing sustenance. He must feed more to get less vitality, all while spreading the disease with each victim.

Hi, I'm Joe Wilcox, a well-known journalist. Over the last year, I wrote five non-fiction eBooks. My Blood is my first fiction work.


Try before You Buy

To give you a sense of the story, I have condensed My Blood's opening chapters into an 8,000-word short that you can download. The draft is a good measure of my storytelling style and sets up the main protagonists and antagonist.

However, the book is a work in progress that likely will not flow the same as the draft, which in condensed form leaves out much of the dialogue and huge chunks of the eventual story. Language needs cleaning up, too, as I am not a French speaker and relied on an Internet translator when preparing the preview version.


The Big Perk

Contributors won't wait months or years to read My Blood. I will begin serializing the book about the time the campaign ends. My Blood will release in chapter chunks with cliffhangers over a number of months before being completed. You will be able to start reading right away. The more money I can raise, particularly beyond the initial funding goal, the more time I can invest in My Blood and the better I can make it for you.


More than Money

Your input will shape the storytelling. Later in the funding campaign, I will set up a method by which contributors can participate in the storytelling process. While I have a clear direction where My Blood will go, I want this book, particularly one embracing a genre as popular as vampires, to be a collective work. You can guide the storytelling. Your ideas matter. The book will leave deliberate hooks—storytelling paths I don't plan to follow—for you to pursue. For example, time-travel isn't on the agenda, but there's a hanging storytelling thread early in the 8,000-word preview should enough readers want it taken up later on.


Big Demands

My Blood can be lots of fun for all of us. My perks ask much, without offering any trinkets, tote bags, or teapots. You give with the promise of getting back a great story and chance to be part of the process.

Download the 8,000-word proof-of-concept version created specifically for the funding campaign and judge by it whether My Blood is worth your blood.


Photo Credit: Tiffany Downes

story:
The Background Story

Thirteen years ago, I finished the first draft of Natural Consequences.  With some enthusiastic encouragement from a few manuscript readers, I picked a half-dozen literary agencies in New York and wrote each a thoughtful query.  

The morning is bright and the air is crisp. At the post office, I take a deep breath and flip through my envelopes one last time. Dropping them into the mail slot, I get a little shiver down my spine. As unceremonious as this act was, it made me feel like a real author -- and I smiled a bit.

 “There’s no reason lucky stars can’t shine on me too,” I think while driving toward my office.

The cell phone rings – it’s my wife.  “Are you listening to the news”? 

“No… why?” I ask.

“A plane just crashed into the World Trade Center,” she replied.

I drove on to work, concerned from hearing the news. My colleagues and I are standing around a television in the conference room, discussing how such a thing could have happened, speculating how difficult it was going to be to extinguish the fire, wondering how long it might take to repair the building.

Then, as we watched, another plane flies out of nowhere and smashes through the second tower. 

We all stop chatting. No desire for speculation. It is crystal clear what is happening, and we all scatter silently to ponder our private thoughts.

There is no comparison of tragedies to be made here. Obviously, the loss for those involved and to our country was staggering; the painful scars remain even today. That I chose that day not only to launch my dreams, but to launch them right into the physical heart of that horror was not lost on me.

I did not expect any responses, but after a few months at least two agencies replied with apologies – though none were expected or necessary. That my book would seem at all relevant or interesting to anyone in America seemed unlikely and unimportant.

Now that thirteen years have passed, I have been thinking again how much I enjoy telling stories. My job is writing computer software, which I have done now for more than thirty years.  Honestly, I do not enjoy writing software -- never dreamed of becoming a software writer, and frankly I am weary of doing it.  

I am a storyteller. I want to write books. I want people to read my books.

Of course, now I am old -- certainly a lot older than I was in 2001. Sometimes computers get to a point where they require a reboot to get things working again. This old man needs a reboot as well, and that is why I am asking for your help.

What I Need & What You Get

I set the goal for this campaign pretty low, because if you do not reach the goal, then the funding organization takes a lot more of a percentage of the funds raised. If the goal is reached, then the fee drops from 9% to 4% -- and that can be a significant difference.

What I truly hope, is that you will get behind this "Reboot the Old Man" effort, and that the $1000 goal will be eclipsed in a spectacular manner. Any amount raised, even if the goal is not fully reached will help me, so rest assured that gratitude does not hinge on the spectacular.

The primary goal is to finish some rewrites and quality editing of the book I set out to publish more than a decade ago. It is finished, and even in its current form it reads pretty well -- still, I want to give it some updates and corrections to match what has changed in the world since it was written.

There is zero danger that Natural Consequences will not be finished and published. Everyone who contributes at any level will receive a 100% off coupon to obtain the book in one of (hopefully) several eBook formats. I plan to do this through the online publishing service called Smashwords. My hope, depending somewhat on the amount of support received, is to have the book available in December of this year.

The other books, should you choose to help me at a higher level, will one day be finished.  You can "vote" for which one comes next by selecting the appropriate perk/contribution level.  The story with the most contribution votes will be the story I finish next, and it will most likely be available around the middle of next year.

My goal is to complete a story in roughly six months.

If you participate at the higher "story-vote" level -- then you will receive a 100% off coupon for ALL of these stories as they are completed, including the first one by the end of this year.


    The Impact

    In a dream of dreams, my job would be to wake up every day to write. There are people who get to do that, and even though it is late in this old man's life -- there has to be a chance for dreams to come true.  

    I hope over time, people will discover that my stories are good and my writing style is enjoyable and comfortable. When that happens, I believe that my dreams can hold their own -- but if enough support comes through this campaign, I can devote more time and mental energy to the effort, increasing the chances for long term success.

    The incredible hope, honestly, is that some kind of record could be set by participants in this "Old Man Reboot" campaign. If enough of you contribute, and spread the word -- the results could be incredibly miraculous.

    Why not make this an extra challenge -- take this campaign to a level never imagined possible. That would be awesome for my dreams, and the added dimension of making fundraising history could be fun as well.

    Just a thought... a dreamer's dream.


      Risks & Challenges

      As I noted before, there is no risk that Natural Consequences will not be published, and virtually no risk that it will not be published before the year's end. There are pressures associated with the work that I do, and lingering challenges that resulted from a rather long period of being unemployed. These are the things that will slow me down, and make it difficult to finish all of the stories. I hope that folks will really get behind me and eliminate the financial distractions. 

      Finishing the stories and publishing them electronically does not depend on fund-raising success.  Allowing my mind to focus on storytelling is at risk if the fund-raising falls too short.


      The Stories

      Natural Consequences
      A fictional tale about an odd weather phenomenon that forms over a rural portion of Nebraska. The story weaves its way through an interesting cast of characters who must confront the growing threat. This book is finished, but is in a re-write and editing phase.

      Sizzlers 
      Have you ever heard of Spontaneous Human Combustion? If it really happens, it certainly is quite rare. Google it if you never have heard of it! What if suddenly everyone begins hearing of Spontaneous Human Combustion? What if becomes very un-rare?

      My Ghost 
      Do you talk to yourself in the car or while you are walking and no one is around?  If you asked yourself a question, and you got a "real" answer -- from the back seat, or from behind you, would you find that "odd"?  Scary?


      The Haunted One 
      Presidents get a lot of advice, and a lot of people watch over them, but when something un-seen by anyone else, begins to visit the President, and make demands, the President becomes a little bit unpredictable. How should the Secret Service deal with that? Hmmm...


      Also... view the cover images and read this text in the Gallery

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Please spread the word -- Take on the challenge -- Reboot the Old Man!

The Background Story 
Thirteen years ago, I finished the first draft of Natural Consequences.  With some enthusiastic encouragement from a few manuscript readers, I picked a half-dozen literary agencies in New York and wrote each a thoughtful query.  
The morning is bright and the air is crisp. At the post office, I take a deep breath and flip through my envelopes one last time. Dropping them into the mail slot, I get a little shiver down my spine. As unceremonious as this act was, it made me feel like a real author -- and I smiled a bit.
 “There’s no reason lucky stars can’t shine on me too,” I think while driving toward my office.
The cell phone rings – it’s my wife.  “Are you listening to the news”? 
“No… why?” I ask.
“A plane just crashed into the World Trade Center,” she replied.
I drove on to work, concerned from hearing the news. My colleagues and I are standing around a television in the conference room, discussing how such a thing could have happened, speculating how difficult it was going to be to extinguish the fire, wondering how long it might take to repair the building.
Then, as we watched, another plane flies out of nowhere and smashes through the second tower. 
We all stop chatting. No desire for speculation. It is crystal clear what is happening, and we all scatter silently to ponder our private thoughts.
There is no comparison of tragedies to be made here. Obviously, the loss for those involved and to our country was staggering; the painful scars remain even today. That I chose that day not only to launch my dreams, but to launch them right into the physical heart of that horror was not lost on me.
I did not expect any responses, but after a few months at least two agencies replied with apologies – though none were expected or necessary. That my book would seem at all relevant or interesting to anyone in America seemed unlikely and unimportant.
Now that thirteen years have passed, I have been thinking again how much I enjoy telling stories. My job is writing computer software, which I have done now for more than thirty years.  Honestly, I do not enjoy writing software -- never dreamed of becoming a software writer, and frankly I am weary of doing it.  
I am a storyteller. I want to write books. I want people to read my books.
Of course, now I am old -- certainly a lot older than I was in 2001. Sometimes computers get to a point where they require a reboot to get things working again. This old man needs a reboot as well, and that is why I am asking for your help.
What I Need & What You Get
 I set the goal for this campaign pretty low, because if you do not reach the goal, then the funding organization takes a lot more of a percentage of the funds raised. If the goal is reached, then the fee drops from 9% to 4% -- and that can be a significant difference.
What I truly hope, is that you will get behind this "Reboot the Old Man" effort, and that the $1000 goal will be eclipsed in a spectacular manner. Any amount raised, even if the goal is not fully reached will help me, so rest assured that gratitude does not hinge on the spectacular.
The primary goal is to finish some rewrites and quality editing of the book I set out to publish more than a decade ago. It is finished, and even in its current form it reads pretty well -- still, I want to give it some updates and corrections to match what has changed in the world since it was written.
There is zero danger that Natural Consequences will not be finished and published. Everyone who contributes at any level will receive a 100% off coupon to obtain the book in one of (hopefully) several eBook formats. I plan to do this through the online publishing service called Smashwords. My hope, depending somewhat on the amount of support received, is to have the book available in December of this year.
The other books, should you choose to help me at a higher level, will one day be finished.  You can "vote" for which one comes next by selecting the appropriate perk/contribution level.  The story with the most contribution votes will be the story I finish next, and it will most likely be available around the middle of next year.
My goal is to complete a story in roughly six months.
If you participate at the higher "story-vote" level -- then you will receive a 100% off coupon for ALL of these stories as they are completed, including the first one by the end of this year.


  The Impact In a dream of dreams, my job would be to wake up every day to write. There are people who get to do that, and even though it is late in this old man's life -- there has to be a chance for dreams to come true.  
I hope over time, people will discover that my stories are good and my writing style is enjoyable and comfortable. When that happens, I believe that my dreams can hold their own -- but if enough support comes through this campaign, I can devote more time and mental energy to the effort, increasing the chances for long term success.
The incredible hope, honestly, is that some kind of record could be set by participants in this "Old Man Reboot" campaign. If enough of you contribute, and spread the word -- the results could be incredibly miraculous.
Why not make this an extra challenge -- take this campaign to a level never imagined possible. That would be awesome for my dreams, and the added dimension of making fundraising history could be fun as well.
Just a thought... a dreamer's dream.




Risks & Challenges As I noted before, there is no risk that Natural Consequences will not be published, and virtually no risk that it will not be published before the year's end. There are pressures associated with the work that I do, and lingering challenges that resulted from a rather long period of being unemployed. These are the things that will slow me down, and make it difficult to finish all of the stories. I hope that folks will really get behind me and eliminate the financial distractions. 
Finishing the stories and publishing them electronically does not depend on fund-raising success.  Allowing my mind to focus on storytelling is at risk if the fund-raising falls too short.


The Stories


Natural Consequences A fictional tale about an odd weather phenomenon that forms over a rural portion of Nebraska. The story weaves its way through an interesting cast of characters who must confront the growing threat. This book is finished, but is in a re-write and editing phase.



Sizzlers Have you ever heard of Spontaneous Human Combustion? If it really happens, it certainly is quite rare. Google it if you never have heard of it! What if suddenly everyone begins hearing of Spontaneous Human Combustion? What if becomes very un-rare?



My Ghost Do you talk to yourself in the car or while you are walking and no one is around?  If you asked yourself a question, and you got a "real" answer -- from the back seat, or from behind you, would you find that "odd"?  Scary?

The Haunted One Presidents get a lot of advice, and a lot of people watch over them, but when something un-seen by anyone else, begins to visit the President, and make demands, the President becomes a little bit unpredictable. How should the Secret Service deal with that? Hmmm...


Also... view the cover images and read this text in the Gallery





Other Ways You Can Help


Please spread the word -- Take on the challenge -- Reboot the Old Man!

story:
Story of My Book

Healthcare of a Thousand Slights
This book seeks to better understand the root causes of health disparities among marginalized communities in the United States by looking back at policies and culture that have helped shape and create those disparities.

My name is Anjana Sreedhar and I am the author of Healthcare of a Thousand Slights. I wrote this book because it is essential to talk about the true root causes of health disparities among marginalized communities (people of color, women, LGBTQ+ community members, and others), and how intrinsically those disparities are connected to the social and economic systems in which people live. More importantly, it is these critical understandings that will draw us to develop more inclusive, integrated solutions to mitigate these health disparities.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover how deeply rooted health disparities are in the history of how different communities have been treated in the United States. In this book, I hope to instill the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for health disparities among marginalized communities in you. And then, ultimately, I want you to see this book as a tool to help you have a more nuanced understanding of the health disparities facing marginalized communities and what opportunities exist to make things better.

In this book, you'll learn about health disparities and systemic injustice and discrimination:

  • how the legacies of policies such as forced relocation, slavery and segregation, and xenophobic immigration policies impacted not just the trajectories of these communities, but also the healthcare they received
  • how movements for civil rights propelled better healthcare provision for different communities
  • how incorporating social determinants of health and leveraging technology responsibly can indeed mitigate health disparities for vulnerable populations

You will love this book if you care deeply about the future of health outcomes for marginalized communities, if you want a deeper understanding of how different systems in the United States function to allow for certain people to have certain healthcare outcomes, and if you are curious about how to improve the quality of life for Americans of color, female-identifying Americans, rural Americans, poor Americans, and LGBTQ+ Americans.

Healthcare of a Thousand Slights is a non-fiction book that speaks to young people in the public health space and those who seek to better understand why different populations have different health outcomes who are looking at health disparities and the history of fighting for civil rights for the first time.

The Book: Healthcare of a Thousand Slights

The book is written in 5 parts....

Part 1: Those Who Were First contains the introduction + the health outcomes and histories of some of America’s earliest residents: Native Americans and Black people. You will learn about the ways in which the United States federal government interacted with these populations over history, ultimately impacting their health access up until today. You will read about researcher Melissa Ojibwe, who shares how traditional farming and hunting practices were disrupted by forced relocation, resulting in a decline in Native American health outcomes; you will also read about Dr. Mary Bassett, who was one of the first to bring #BlackLivesMatter to the forefront of medicine.

Part 2: Those Who Came Later contains chapters detailing the history of the migration of Latine Americans and Asian Americans. I interviewed people like reproductive health justice advocate, Jessica Gonzalez-Rojas, about the unique challenges of Latine Americans in accessing reproductive and general healthcare, while also getting insights from researchers, such as Dr. Stella Yi of NYU Langone Health’s Center for the Study of Asian American Health, about the challenges of the model minority myth on the health of lower-income Asian Americans.

Part 3: Those Who Have Been Forgotten highlights the healthcare challenges faced by poor and rural Americans. While the narratives of these Americans has often been left out of mainstream media and academic conversation, I am excited to share that I’ve had the chance to learn from author Linda Tirado, who brought the struggles of poor Americans to the forefront with her book and from researchers at the Bipartisan Policy Center for sharing key reforms that would improve health outcomes for rural Americans.

Part 4: Bringing Past Movements to the Fore highlights the healthcare challenges faced by American women and LGBTQ+ people. In the 1960s, women’s liberation and LGBTQ+ rights movements were coming to the forefront; what I seek to do is highlight the effects of those movements on the health outcomes on these populations.

Part 5: An Ode To COVID-19 and Moving Forward is highly topical, including technology and policy solutions designed to mitigate health disparities. Given the COVID-19 pandemic and the resurgence of racial injustice in national conversations due to the murder of George Floyd, I have included some interviews from frontline workers and analysis on the future of healthcare for marginalized communities with racial injustice in mind.

What I Need and What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:

  • The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in December 2020
  • The Cover Design of my Book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!
  • The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)
  • The Copyediting for My Book - to make help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication
  • The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this winter
When I pre-sell 120 copies of my book, I will publish. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish a hardcover edition. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition and an audiobook.

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:
  • You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish
  • A Personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book
  • Your Name will appear in a Special, Acknowledgements Section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”)
  • Early access to the Introduction of my Book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback
  • The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
  • I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share experience the experiences of writing my book

And more...

About the Author

Anjana Sreedhar is an administrative fellow at NYU Langone Health in New York City. She is a recent graduate of NYU’s Wagner School of Public Service’s Masters in Public Administration - Health Policy & Management program. She previously worked at Advisory Board, a healthcare research and consulting firm, in best practice research and strategic marketing. As a former student activist and promoter of diversity, equity, inclusion, and anti-racism, Anjana comes into the healthcare space with a keen understanding of the dynamics of power and policy and how it affects quality of life for those who live in America.

She is passionate about this topic because in her experience, the key linkages between history, policy, advocacy, and health outcomes are not always explicitly made. In order to understand current healthcare outcomes among marginalized communities — and what to do about them — she believes that we need to look back into our past to understand how marginalized communities were treated and how that ultimately affected their healthcare and quality of life.

Outside of writing this book, Anjana enjoys singing opera, Broadway, and pop songs around the house and on stage, drinking copious amounts of chai, and walking the streets of New York City with no purpose. She also loves spending time with her parents and sister, and being involved in community causes.

For more information you can connect with her at anjana.sreedhar@nyu.edu and on LinkedIn [https://www.linkedin.com/in/anjanasreedhar/] and Instagram [@anjana.sreedhar01]. She also has a personal website [https://anjanasreedhar.strikingly.com].

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please Share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #HealthcareofAThousandSlights and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press so we can help amplify your efforts.

You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page

Please share my book to 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or Direct Message on social media.

Thank you so much for of all of your love and support!

Thanks again,
Anjana Sreedhar

story:
Thank You for Stopping By!

My name is Jonas Lee. I'm an Indie author who has already published a recent novel, A Time to Reap. This campaign is an effort to get its sequel out by the time the first book starts receiving traction. As a new author, I am basically invisible until I can get my foot in the door. 

Satisfying Our Needs

This is an effort to get publishing costs covered and marketing funds underway. So, yes, I need your money, BUT I will give you things in return. I'm not just a charity case. I'm looking to reach at least $2500 dollars. This will cover the following:

  • Editing
  • Formatting
  • Cover Art
  • Branding
  • Fundraising Costs

And with your donation, I will give you the option of various perks for helping me out. It can go to something as simple as a public thank you to signed copies of books. I can show up for a book club or have the option of becoming a name WITHIN the new book!!

Now, it's possible that not everyone will be able to donate what they wish they could. I get it, we don't all have money to dish out at any given time. So, in the unlikely case I don't meet the full goal, I will still be using what is raised for the essential things first. Cover art is a must. If any of you liked the first cover, I want to carry that awesomeness over. Then the technical side to make the mistakes of my existence pretty much disappear.

The plus side... If I raise more than what the base goal is, the branding cost will go straight into marketing and I will get something for everyone. Not ruining the surprise yet. Don't want to jinx it.

Antsy Pants

This project is crucial for getting the sequel up and running. Not to say it won't happen in time, but who wants to wait for an additional 4-8 months to find out what Carter & Mo are up to??

As an Indie author, I love creating the story I want to tell and giving it to an audience. I have no publishing house, unfortunately, so I must do all of these things out of my own pocket. Sales from the first book will get there, but not for another four months or so.

Writing is my dream, I'm living it and breathing it in daily. My waking world is still a full-time job, a family and a daughter who loves to be involved in sports. So many friends and family have already helped me live this dream in so many ways, I just don't want to wake up from it yet. Help me hit the Snooze button a little longer, would you?

The Junk Punch

This is a section (title renamed of course) Indie Go-Go adds to keep a transparency on what might come up. Truly, nothing will stop this from becoming a reality. Granted, if I can't raise enough funds, it will be slower.

Beyond that, the book is done. I just finished it a couple days ago. No wondering when I'll get around to it. Literally, from fundraising I'll be setting up appointments to get things rolling.

    Other Athithtance

    Perhaps banking on a future project isn't your style. Or you think because you're here, you have to spend money. I'd love your money, granted, I'm sure it's burning a hole in your pocket. I have a fire extinguisher AND taken safety courses. I can handle it.

    If you would rather help me along in your own special, secretive way, feel free to pick up a copy of the book that's already out. It's available on Kindle, Nook, Kobo and in Paperback through CreateSpace.

    And if you made it this far and still aren't convinced in letting go of that burning money, I'd appreciate it if you could spread the word to friends and family across all your social media. You can check out mine below!

And if you made it this far and still aren't convinced in letting go of that burning money, I'd appreciate it if you could spread the word to friends and family across all your social media. You can check out mine below!

story:
Que?

Viúvas de vivos e de mortos é unha desas novela que invitan a continuar lendo, ofrecendo contrastes e desenvolvendo novas tramas e conflictos a medida que as súas protagonistas tratan de resolver os seus problemas... de vivir as súas vidas.

Dous vellos mariñeiros atopan o cadáver dun home aboiando nas augas do peirao de pasaxeiros de Moaña. Un intrigante suceso que vai quebrar a forzada tranquilidade dos anos da posguerra da pequena vila mariñeira, traendo consigo unha cadea de sorprendentes revelacións que van alterar a vida dos seus habitantes.

Especialmente a triste vida de Penélope. Penélope Laura. Laura A tola, viúva de vivo.

Quen?

Do Peirao é unha editorial con vontade de cambio, de publicar obras poco convencionais pero de incuestionable calidade, con novas e refrescantes ideas como é o empregar unha campaña preventa para valorar a aceptación e viabilidade de cada título.

Deste xeito es ti, agora que te estás expondo como colaborar, o que decide se a obra que che presentamos verá a luz pasando a formar parte do noso catálogo... porque consideramos ao lector parte fundamental do proceso.

Hoxe preséntasenos Serafín Parcero.

Nacín un nun caloroso 25 de xullo, o de 1955, no lugar da Praia, en Moaña. Gradueime en Profesorado de EXB na Escola Universitaria de Formación do Profesorado de EXB de Pontevedra. O meu primeiro destino como mestre foi o C.P. Reibón, en Moaña. Logo desenvolvín o meu labor docente en diversos centros educativos da provincia de Pontevedra. Dende moi novo participei de modo activo na vida social, cultural e deportiva da miña vila natal. Tamén dende novo me sentín atraído pola creación artística, en especial polo debuxo e a escrita. As influencias da miña profesión leváronme cara o conto e o teatro para nenos.

No ano 2000 abracei con ilusión un subxénero literario que antes nunca profanara: o microrrelato. Un amor —creo que mutuo— que segue vivo e dando os seus froitos. Ese ano, un dos meus microrrelatos, o que leva por título «Contrabando» foi merecedor do primeiro premio no Certame de Microrrelatos convocado pola Lonxa Literaria de Moaña. Ese mesmo ano, o conto da miña autoría «O verán no que Manolo Escobar veu actuar nas festas do Cristo» foi, igualmente, merecedor do primeiro premio de Narracións Breves convocado pola AA VV Nós, de San Pedro de Darbo. Volvín presentar unha obra a ese mesmo certame, desta vez na edición do 2004, sendo merecedor, novamente, do máximo galardón coa miña obra Aconteceu nun outono que se negaba a selo. No ano 2008  gañei o Certame de Relatos de Muller "Matilde Bares", convocado polo CIM do Concello de Bueu coa obra Ollos de cinsa (esgotada a primeira edición). A finais do ano 2016 rematei a miña novela Insulae Deorum e presenteina ao Concurso de Novela Torreste Ballester. A convocatoria dese ano bateu todos os récords de participación, cun total de 101 novelas na modalidade de lingua galega. De entre elas o xurado escolleu 18 finalistas, entre as que estaba a miña obra. Obra que editei e que está a acadar recoñecemento entre os lectores.

Se desexades coñecer máis da miña obra, podedes visitar a miña páxina literaria: www.bicebersa.com

Por que?

Por aquí un fragmento do texto como mostra:

«Baixou do barco de pasaxe e, xa nas escadas do peirao, volveu botar man do paquete do tabaco. Fretou con enerxía un mixto contra do rugoso lateral da diminuta caixa de cartón, e cando achegaba a pequena candea ao cigarro, albiscou algo que chamou a súa atención naquela lámina de prata escura coa que a incipiente luz do día tapizaba as remansadas augas superficiais do peirao. Coa man que o cigarro deixaba libre turrou daquel cabo que, mediante un sinxelo sistema de nó escorregadizo debería achegar a embarcación onda el, máis a embarcación, trancada, negábase teimuda ao solicitado desprazamento. O seu corazón detivo o compasado latexar cando albiscou, enleado entre os cabos do bote e os dunha chalana que estaba fondeada fronte das escaleiras de ferro do peirao, un vulto informe. Aínda que a súa vista non era, nin moito menos a de antano, por causa do glaucoma recentemente diagnosticado e que galopaba sen control cara a unha paulatina e inexorable perda do seu campo visual, enseguida se fixo unha idea certeira da natureza daquel obxecto que, aboiando entre augas, impedía que a vella embarcación se achegase ao peirao con facilidade.
          O corazón, súbita e brevemente pausado, recuperou o palpitar, agora cunha rapidez e intensidade fóra do común, a causa dunha idea tan tola como efémera: o mar quería devolverlle aquilo que lle arrincara con tanta crueldade, o mar desexaba tornáballe a parte mortal do seu fillo querido para que, por fin, puidera repousar en terreo sagrado.
          Aquela amarga, mais, á súa vez, reconfortante ilusión durou escasos segundos, os suficientes para deixalo embargado nunha tristura e nun desacougo profundos».

Como?

Para arrincar o proxecto fixámonos como obxectivo 880€; esta é a cantidade que recadariamos se ao redor de cincuenta mecenas se fixesen, cada cal, cun exemplar desta primeira edición.

  • Tendo acceso ás galeradas de edición.
  • Recibindo un exemplar semanas antes da saída ao mercado da obra.
  • Aínda que, tamén poderías ver o teu nome nos agradecementos achegando un pouco máis.

Ademais...

Sabemos que son tempos difíciles, tamén nós os sufrimos, e é posible que non esteas en disposición de apoiarnos co teu mecenado nestes momentos... pero agardamos que se isto te chegou á alma, mesmo se talvez coñeces en persoa ao autor, trates de difundir esta campaña (facebook, twitter, blogger, boca-orella... ) para que academos a nosa meta e Serafín Parcero vexa publicada a súa obra.

Grazas polo voso tempo.

Política de privacidade
story_txt:
Que?
Viúvas de vivos e de mortos é unha desas novela que invitan a continuar lendo, ofrecendo contrastes e desenvolvendo novas tramas e conflictos a medida que as súas protagonistas tratan de resolver os seus problemas... de vivir as súas vidas.
Dous vellos mariñeiros atopan o cadáver dun home aboiando nas augas do peirao de pasaxeiros de Moaña. Un intrigante suceso que vai quebrar a forzada tranquilidade dos anos da posguerra da pequena vila mariñeira, traendo consigo unha cadea de sorprendentes revelacións que van alterar a vida dos seus habitantes.
Especialmente a triste vida de Penélope. Penélope Laura. Laura A tola, viúva de vivo.
Quen?
Do Peirao é unha editorial con vontade de cambio, de publicar obras poco convencionais pero de incuestionable calidade, con novas e refrescantes ideas como é o empregar unha campaña preventa para valorar a aceptación e viabilidade de cada título.
Deste xeito es ti, agora que te estás expondo como colaborar, o que decide se a obra que che presentamos verá a luz pasando a formar parte do noso catálogo... porque consideramos ao lector parte fundamental do proceso.
Hoxe preséntasenos Serafín Parcero.
Nacín un nun caloroso 25 de xullo, o de 1955, no lugar da Praia, en Moaña. Gradueime en Profesorado de EXB na Escola Universitaria de Formación do Profesorado de EXB de Pontevedra. O meu primeiro destino como mestre foi o C.P. Reibón, en Moaña. story:
I plan to visit all 251 countries of the world. And hitchhiking only. No buses, no trains, no planes. Only hitchhiking by autos and ships. And want to write How-To Guide for Hitchhiking Anywhere on the Planet.

Throughout this journey, I intend to keep notes, get to know local residents, and document through photography.

These will all be formatted into blogs where internet access is available,

then posted online to share with whomever desires to read them. This is not a profit-making venture.

I only intend to help others cope with their illness by sharing my own experiences and answering any questions they may have.

However, I think this can be a genuine benefit to any readers who may ultimately consider doing this type of travel themselves, or anyone who can simply find solace in knowing another soul is out there using any means necessary to cope with illness and difficulty in their lives.

I plan to stay with locals as much as possible, through couchsurfing, hostels, friends, and any other means, I want to learn the cultures, interact with the people, find the hidden gems, and let my backers see, and hear from the locals, for those that cannot travel for whatever reason, they can live their dreams through my blogs, for those that have travelled, they can give me advice, and for those that have immigrated, they can help me out when I am in their native land. I believe it will be an education beyond what any institution could provide, and with this new found knowledge I would like to share it in as many ways possible, perhaps through a "YouTube”. I hope I reach my goal, as it's the only way I could really afford this dream, and that I am able to share it with you every step of the way.

story:
Our Story

My name is juju angeles and I am a poet, a student, an educator, a subsidized printer, an activist, and a mother. I have taught and read all around New York. I have volunteered my time with several organizations, including NY2NO, an organization that works in the Lower 9th Ward in New Orleans. I was also on Brave New Voices NY slam team, and taped for HBO's Def Poetry. In 2009, I founded Zion Imprints. 

I just finished my junior year in my Creative Writing program at Purchase College and I was recently accepted to join Vona Voices, which gives me the chance to study with Ruth Forman and other writers-of-color.  This is a nice change of pace for me because Vona Voices is an organization that provides workshop space for writers- of-color to explore their voice, style and culture in an understanding environment. This year Vona Voices is hosted at UC Berkley in California. 

Although, I learned a lot this past semester at Purchase's program, I also lacked the guidance as a writer and as a cultural being. I often felt out of place and misrepresented. This concerns me because I am working on a manuscript of poems for my Senior Project, which I need in order to graduate and which will be graded by my program. I generated a lot of work this past year and I want to take the best of that batch and present it to another audience, the audience I am often talking to in my work.  

I am also applying to MFA programs in Poetry and I envision this chance as a way to explore my poetry in a supportive environment so as to make my writing tighter and therefore, increase my chance of getting into a graduate program.



The Impact

I am giver. I call myself a subsidized printer because I make chapbooks for poets at a discounted cost. I put the work in because I am a believer in the healing power of words. I am a believer in craft. And I am a believer in artist development and I try to make publishing as much of a possibility as possible. 

Print production sometimes is too expensive for some amazing poets, so in the effort of expanding opportunity to everyone, I make chapbooks relatively cheap. I also publish poets for free through a writing contest. All of this comes out of my own pockets.

I want to continue this venture, I want to continue making chapbooks. Chapbooks have a wonderful history and are an affordable luxury, but I also need to write and take care of my voice, so that I can have a positive impact on my own life, my daughter's life, and my community, as well. 

I want to use this workshop experience not only to publish my own work, but to continue to use poetry as a way to publish and teach literacy. Poetry is a powerful tool in external and internal literacy. Poetry makes connections.

For those of you who don't know my personally, I am a single-mother in all senses of the word. Yet, I am very blessed because I pay our bills on time and I am getting an education. We manage by the support and aid of our family and friends. There small contributions help in huge and impacting ways. 


I have already paid for my flight to get to California, so if I do not raise the money in time (by June 6th) I will lose that money and the opportunity to work with amazing writers. 


What We Need & What You Get

My balance, including room and board is $1050. The money will be used to directly fund the expenses related to Vona Voices and feeding myself in California. It will also help to pay for babysitting for my wonderful four year old. 


If you donate $5, I will send you a digital (PDF) copy of my chapbook, "He Art".

If you donate $10, I will send you an autographed, hardcopy of my chapbook, "He Art"

If you donate $25, I will send you a hardcopy of my chapbook, "He Art" and a $10 coupon for a black and white print run of your chapbook, business card, or fliers. 

If you donate $50, I will send you all of the above and write you an haiku about the nature of your wonderfulness!

If you donate $100, I will send you all of the above and I will read at your next venue, permitting that it is a short ride away through the MTA's travel system.

If you donate $200, I will send you all of the above and l will teach a workshop on poetry to 15 maximum students.



Other Ways You Can Help

Others way that you can help is my spreading the word through Facebook, Twitter, Word of Mouth or any other forms of social networking. 

You can also hire me to make some chapbooks for you as well. For more information on that, write me at zionimprints@gmail.com

Thank you for your time and visiting my fundraising page.

story:
Keep Cave Canem in the house!

When you donate to Cave Canem’s Rent Party, you help sustain the nation’s premier home for Black poetry. Your gift ensures that the many voices of African American poets will continue to be heard.

Every year, Cave Canem staff raises money from foundations and government sources for programs that are transforming the literary landscape and changing individual ives: an annual retreat for 54 emerging African American poets, community workshops that have served hundreds since 1999, the Cave Canem Poetry Prize, New Works readings, and many more events and opportunities. Unfortunately, the reality is that grants cover only a small percentage of overhead, including rent, the single most challenging line item in our budget.

While the spirit of Cave Canem is evident throughout New York City and beyond, maintaining a centralized hub is vital to the work we do. Our headquarters in DUMBO, Brooklyn has been blessed by the presence of poets at all career stages, and many a poem (perhaps one of yours) has been conceived within these walls.  Our airy loft overlooking the East River is a welcoming, safe space for workshops, readings, research and conversations, and serves as a gallery for exhibiting visual art. For staff, fellows, board members and volunteers, having a physical site to plan, fundraise and prepare programs is key. Like most rental space in New York City, however, it comes with a hefty price tag.

Rent parties began in Harlem in the 1920s when cash-strapped Uptown residents devised creative ways to pay discriminatory rental rates on low salaries. Party hosts opened their homes, and in exchange for a small cover charge, prepared food and provided live entertainment. Together, party goers defeated eviction, while eating, drinking, dancing and socializing for much less than what they’d pay for a night on the town. Everybody won!

What We Need & What You Get

Cave Canem’s coast-to-coast Virtual & Actual Rent Parties revive the Harlem-style rent party with poetry at its core! Join the party and help us raise $20,000 to defray our $45,000 rent bill in 2014. When you give, you will you have our deep gratitude, receive distinctive perks, and most importantly, have the satisfaction of knowing that you are making a positive difference to the future of American poetry. 

CCVRP - SOUTH perks include: 

  • "Dog Print" acknowledgement on your facebook wall and thank you poem email. 
  • Poetry from southern Cave Canem fellows - shirlette ammons, Stephanie Pruitt, Remica L. Bingham-Risher, Amanda Johnston, L. Lamar Wilson, M. Ayodele Heath, Jonathan Moody, Cedric Tillman, Kwoya Fagin Maples and Bianca Spriggs. 
  • New music by blues funk musician shirlette ammons. 
  • Unique mason jars full of creative goodness. 
  • A limited broadside featuring new artwork by Wura-Natasha Ogunji.
  • Poetry over the phone from Cave Canem founder Cornelius Eady and U.S. Poet Laureate Natasha Trethewey. 
  • *Allow 2-3 days for delivery of $10 - 24 perks. Allow two weeks for delivery of $25 and up perks. 

History 

Cave Canem Foundation is a home for the many voices of African American poetry and is committed to cultivating the artistic and professional growth of African American poets. A 501(c)(3) non-profit service and presenting literary organization with administrative and programming headquarters in Brooklyn, NY, Cave Canem was founded in 1996 by Toi Derricotte and Cornelius to remedy the under-representation and isolation of African American poets in MFA programs and writing workshops.

Over the past 17 years, the organization has grown from an initial gathering of 26 poets to become an influential movement with a renowned faculty and a high-achieving national fellowship of 371. Cave Canem poets are influencing the literary landscape and inspiring the genesis of such organizations as Kundiman,a national organization dedicated to the creation and cultivation of Asian American poetry, and CantoMundo, which provides a space for the creation, documentation and critical analysis of Latina/o poetry.

With an annual week-long writing retreat, community based workshops, publications, nationally based readings and Poets on Craft conversations, Cave Canem programs bring previously marginalized voices to the center of cultural awareness and the popular imagination. Cave Canem annually engages approximately 250 writers with readings, panels and opportunities to lead community-based workshops in New York City and Pittsburgh, which have served 600 emerging poets of color since 1999. We partner with six prestigious presses to deliver a first-book prize (13 collections to date), a second-book prize and anthologies; together, our publications reach a national readership of thousands.

Cave Canem enjoys over 20 local, regional and national cultural partnerships, among them the Brooklyn Book Festival, where we are a Programming Partner; the Association of Writers and Writing Programs Conference, where we are a Literary Partner; and five collaborative residencies at such sites as the Millay Colony for the Arts, Vermont Studio Center and City of Asylum/Pittsburgh. Our social media network includes over 7,440 Facebook fans and friends, 2,846 Twitter followers, 13,420–plus YouTube views and 51,000 annual website visits.

Awards garnered by fellows include, among many others, the Rona Jaffe Foundation Writers’ Award, Whiting Writers' Award, NAACP Image Award, the Academy of American Poets’ Laughlin Award, National Poetry Series Selection, Cave Canem Poetry Prize, and Guggenheim and Ruth Lilly Fellowships. Fellows have 180+ books in print and have gained significant footholds in academic positions around the country. Faculty member Elizabeth Alexander was named President Obama’s Inaugural Poet in 2008; faculty members Terrance Hayes and Nikky Finney won the National Book Award for Poetry in 2010 and 2011, respectively; 2002 Cave Canem Poetry Prize winner Tracy K. Smith received the 2012 Pulitzer Prize for Poetry; and Natasha Trethewey, faculty member and inaugural winner of the Cave Canem Poetry Prize, currently serves as U. S. Poet Laureate.

airy loft overlooking the East River is a welcoming, safe space for workshops,
readings, research and conversations, and serves as a gallery for exhibiting visual
art. For staff, fellows, board members and volunteers, having a physical site
to plan, fundraise and prepare programs is key. Like most rental space in New
York City, however, it comes with a hefty price tag. Rent parties began in Harlem in the 1920s
when cash-strapped Uptown residents devised creative ways to pay discriminatory
rental rates on low salaries. Party hosts opened their homes, and in exchange
for a small cover charge, prepared food and provided live entertainment.
Together, party goers defeated eviction, while eating, drinking, dancing and
socializing for much less than what they’d pay for a night on the town.
Everybody won!What We Need & What You GetCave Canem’s coast-to-coast Virtual & Actual Rent Parties revive the Harlem-style rent party with poetry at its core! Join the party and help us raise $20,000 to defray our $45,000 rent bill in 2014. When you give, you will you have our deep gratitude, receive distinctive perks, and most importantly, have the satisfaction of knowing that you are making a positive difference to the future of American poetry. CCVRP - SOUTH perks include: 
"Dog Print" acknowledgement on your facebook wall and thank you poem email. 
Poetry from southern Cave Canem fellows - shirlette ammons, Stephanie Pruitt, Remica L. Bingham-Risher, Amanda Johnston, L. Lamar Wilson, M. Ayodele Heath, Jonathan Moody, Cedric Tillman, Kwoya Fagin Maples and Bianca Spriggs. 
New music by blues funk musician shirlette ammons. 
Unique mason jars full of creative goodness. 
A limited broadside featuring new artwork by Wura-Natasha Ogunji.
Poetry over the phone from Cave Canem founder Cornelius Eady and U.S. Poet Laureate Natasha Trethewey. 
*Allow 2-3 days for delivery of $10 - 24 perks. Allow two weeks for delivery of $25 and up perks. 

History 
Cave Canem Foundation is a home for the many voices of African American
poetry and is committed to cultivating the artistic and professional growth of
African American poets. A 501(c)(3)
non-profit service and presenting literary organization with administrative and
programming headquarters in Brooklyn, NY, Cave Canem was founded in 1996 by Toi
Derricotte and Cornelius to remedy the under-representation and isolation of
African American poets in MFA programs and writing workshops.
Over the past 17 years, the
organization has grown from an initial gathering of 26 poets to become an
influential movement with a renowned faculty and a high-achieving national
fellowship of 371. Cave Canem poets are influencing the literary landscape and
inspiring the genesis of such organizations as Kundiman,a national organization dedicated to
the creation and cultivation of Asian American poetry, and CantoMundo, which provides a space for the creation,
documentation and critical analysis of Latina/o poetry.
With an annual week-long writing
retreat, community based workshops, publications, nationally based readings and
Poets on Craft conversations, Cave Canem
programs bring previously marginalized voices to the center of cultural
awareness and the popular imagination. Cave Canem annually engages
approximately 250 writers with readings, panels and opportunities to lead
community-based workshops in New York City and Pittsburgh, which have served 600
emerging poets of color since 1999. We
partner with six prestigious presses to deliver a first-book prize (13
collections to date), a second-book prize and anthologies; together, our publications
reach a national readership of thousands.Cave Canem enjoys over 20 local, regional and national cultural
partnerships, among them the Brooklyn Book Festival, where we are a Programming
Partner; the Association of Writers and Writing Programs Conference, where we
are a Literary Partner; and five collaborative residencies at such sites as the
Millay Colony for the Arts, Vermont Studio Center and City of
Asylum/Pittsburgh. Our social media network includes over 7,440 Facebook fans
and friends, 2,846 Twitter followers, 13,420–plus YouTube views and 51,000
annual website visits. 
Awards
garnered by fellows include, among many others, the Rona Jaffe Foundation
Writers’ Award, Whiting Writers' Award, NAACP Image Award, the Academy of
American Poets’ Laughlin Award, National Poetry Series Selection, Cave Canem
Poetry Prize, and Guggenheim and Ruth Lilly Fellowships. Fellows have 180+
books in print and have gained significant footholds in academic positions
around the country. Faculty member Elizabeth Alexander was named President
Obama’s Inaugural Poet in 2008; faculty members Terrance Hayes and Nikky Finney
won the National Book Award for Poetry in 2010 and 2011, respectively; 2002
Cave Canem Poetry Prize winner Tracy K. Smith received the 2012 Pulitzer Prize
for Poetry; and Natasha Trethewey, faculty member and inaugural winner of the
Cave Canem Poetry Prize, currently serves as U. S. Poet Laureate.

story:
My name is Janet Ravare Colson, and I was born and raised Creole in Los Angeles, California.  Way back when, I met and married a Louisiana man and moved to the â€œchosen land,â€ as my father called it, the home of so many Creole families, Cane River in Natchitoches Parish, Louisiana. 


Creoles are generally known as a people of mixed French, African, Spanish, and Native American ancestry, most of who reside in or have familial ties to Louisiana. Creole is a culture, not a race and is based on shared experiences, traits, traditions, familial ties and histories. Their culture and heritage, rarely acknowledged in spite of its uniqueness, is worthy and deserving of attention and preservation; without it an important part of the American experience could be lost.


About THE Book

After serving as Executive Director of the Creole Heritage Center since 1998 I retired this past December.  I am now able to devote my time in other directions, I wanted to give an inside look at how the Center developed and grew.  Iâ€™m working on a publication entitled THE Creole Book which traces the history, accomplishments and milestones of the Center. The planned 100-150 page book will include a textual and pictorial overview of the Centerâ€™s work and accomplishments including:

 

â€¢          national outreach programs and the results;

â€¢          projects and their products;

â€¢          wealth of research and documentation;

â€¢          Creoles yesterday, today, and tomorrow; and

â€¢          partnerships formed with mutually benefitting achievements and objectives realized.

 

In addition to presenting history and activities of the Center, other topics will be presented through articles such as the following:

 

v The First Time I Heard â€œCreoleâ€ in Louisiana; a personal perspective from a California lady

v My Grandmother was Indian; a look at identifying your Native American connection

v She Wasnâ€™t BORN Married!; things to consider when documenting family history

v Letâ€™s Party, Creole Style; Creoles celebrating (and learning) about their music, foods, traditions, legacies and more.

v Did You Hear What Happened to LOU?;  a revealing look at the possible loss of a treasured Creole practice

v Social Media â€“ The Good, The Bad and The WRONG Information; Why facts are better than fiction.

v What If It Were All In One Place?; A discussion about the only central clearinghouse of Creole related data along with content descriptions and listings. 

v Itâ€™s ALL in on the Internet â€“ NOT; To use or not to use information from the Internet.


The Creole Heritage Center

Through a series of events in the mid-1990s, a Creole Heritage Center was developed and placed at Northwestern State University in Natchitoches, Louisiana.  My first thought as we began was, this is wonderful, but what IS a Creole Heritage Center?  What are we suppose to do??  There was no model to follow; this was (and is) the first and only one of its kind in America.  All I knew is that it was time that our culture received the recognition it deserves and no longer be the known as the â€œForgotten Peopleâ€.


In its thirteen+ years of existence, the Center has served not only the Creoles in Louisiana, but the national Creoles public, scholars, and anyone interested in the culture from around the entire US and even other countries.  It has paved the way for the long sought after recognition of the unique and deserving Creole culture.  The Center has also become the national Creole voice.   To put it bluntly, Creoles can now be comfortable in declaring their culture and heritage.  It is my belief that this would not be possible without the work that the Creole Center has done.

 

Over a thousand comments were received as a part of a recent online survey; shown below is a very small sampling:

 

The services that the Louisiana Creole Heritage Center provides have been invaluable in my research.   In addition, as a genealogist and researcher of history, I cannot stress how important the Creole Center can be in educating future generations about the legacy of the Creole people.  TEXAS

 

I'm a researcher on Creole issues, based in the UK, so some of this does not apply, but I'm very grateful to Janet and her colleagues for her help. FRANCE

 

The Louisiana Creole Heritage Center is currently our ONLY CHANCE to have a central location which is dedicated to investigating and preserving information on our heritage.  I believe that our heritage is too UNIQUE to be forgotten.  It would be a great loss to all who believe in the influence of ancestry.  Their actions, their drive and dedication are a huge part of where we are and what makes us who we are!   ILLINOIS
